title: astonishing-level-of-dog-dirt-on-sports-pitches-in-tranent
story: Sports clubs are working alongside East Lothian Council in a bid to reduce the number of people failing to clear up after their pets.Three blackspots in the area have been identied ndash Polson Park, Meadowmill and Ross High playing fields ndash and Councillor Colin McGinn described the amount of dog fouling as ldquoastonishing.He said: ldquoWhat is currently happening is the rugby club and Tranent Colts, who use Ross High playing fields, they have to send out a group of coaches or officials to walk the pitches and clear up the mess before they start playing. Runners at Meadowmill, or even the cricket club, are having to go out and make sure the training areas are clean before they start.ldquoFolk want to just turn up and get fit or improve their wellbeing without having to resort to clearing up dog mess before any activity.ldquoIt is irresponsible and pretty uncaring from people.Mr McGinn, who lives in Tranent, visited Meadowmill alongside representatives from ious East Lothian Council departments, including environmental health.The councillor described the situation as ldquoa disgrace, with a campaign to be launched in the coming weeks.Adam Hook, head coach at Ross High RFC, agreed it was a major problem.He said: ldquoIt is really frustrating. You can imagine we are trying to get warmed up and someone stops playing after spotting dog mess on the pitch. Someone then has got to take time out to clear it up and it impacts the warm up or during the game.Mr Hook was keen to see more regular patrols carried out by dog wardens in an attempt to catch irresponsible pet owners.He added: ldquoThey should hit them in the pocket and seethey do it again.ldquoIt is just total laziness. I know lots of people with dogs that would never dream of doing it.Phil Purves, chairman of Tranent Colts, agreed that it was a problem which was getting worse.He told the Courier: ldquoIt is very frustrating.ldquo[Clearing dog fouling] is something we have done pretty much all the time we have coached but it is out of control now.ldquoWe had a game two weeks ago and had to clean up  piles off one pitch.The club has recently bought a dog fouling bin to be put near the playing fields in a bid to encourage owners to clean up after their pets.A spokeswoman for East Lothian Council said: ldquoThe council has noted an increase in complaints about dog fouling in recent weeks, particularly within grass sports areas and school grounds.ldquoOptions are currently being considered as to how best to tackle this situation and will be communicated in due course. In the meantime, all dog owners are reminded of their legal and moral responsibility to clean up after their dog and dispose of the waste properly.

title: new-affordable-homes-in-ormiston-approved
story: The  new homes off the villagersquos Tynemount Road will be part of a larger development by Walker Homes. In total,  properties are being built at the site.East Lothian Councilrsquos planning department gave the scheme the go-ahead last week, with  affordable houses and  flats to be built on the site.The housing will be a mix of council homes and mid-market rentals.Each of the new homes will be classed as affordable housing, with the  flats comprising of six semi-detached two-storey flatted buildings with two bedrooms, and four semi-detached two-storey flats with one bedroom in each.Ten of the houses will be semi-detached, with three terraced properties and two detached homes.Sixteen of the properties will have three bedrooms, with the remaining house containing two bedrooms.A spokeswoman for East Lothian Council said: ldquoWe are delighted to be creating more affordable housing units in Ormiston.ldquoAt least  of these will be new council houses.ldquoWe are currently in discussion with another affordable housing provider to potentially deliver  of the units for mid-market rent, creating a mixed tenure development to meet the ied needs of our communities.Meanwhile, more than pound, will be split between the villagersquos primary school and Ross High School in Tranent to ensure that there is sufficient educational capacity to serve the housing.A sum of pound, will go towards Ormiston Primary School, with a further pound, going to the secondary school.Haddington and Lammermuir ward member Councillor Shamin Akhtar was delighted with the additional housing. She said: ldquoIt is good news that permission has been granted for  council houses and  affordable homes for rent in Ormiston.ldquoThese are much-needed homes and will be welcomed by the local community.

title: longniddry-schoolgirl-meets-nicola-sturgeon-over-bubbles-campaign
story: Ellie McIntyre champions Longniddry Primary Schoolrsquos Bubbles Beat Balloons campaign, which encourages people to blow eco-friendly bubbles as an alternative to releasing balloons at public celebrations or tribute events.The youngster wrote to First Minister Nicola Sturgeon, who invited the eight-year-old to the Scottish Parliament to discuss the scheme further.The P pupil received a letter from Ms Sturgeonrsquos office highlighting the importance of young people being involved in developing initiatives and taking them forward.Ellie, who lives in Tranent, said: ldquoIt was exciting to meet Nicola Sturgeon and she let me have a selfie with her.ldquoI was happy she was able to sign our pledge.The youngster was joined at Holyrood by her mum Pauline, as well as her class teacher Yvonne Hart.The group were given a tour of the building, before meeting Ms Sturgeon and sitting in at First Ministerrsquos Questions. Ellie took a framed campaign certicate and Ms Sturgeon signed the lsquoBubbles Beat Balloonsrsquo pledge.Miss Hart added: ldquoThe First Minister was clearly impressed by Ellie and was keen to sign our campaign.ldquoFor her to make time in her busy schedule like this was amazing!The environmental campaign was launched by the school, which is home to  pupils, last summer.After participating in a One Planet One Future project and watching the BBCrsquos Blue Planet  programme ndash which highlighted the devastating impact of plastic on wildle and nature ndash the pupils decided to take action.The children learnt that mass balloon releases were often used when celebrating events or for remembering loved ones. So they decided the much-loved childrenrsquos pastime of blowing bubbles was a much more environmentally friendly way of marking special events instead of polluting the planet with latex balloons.The initiative has already been backed by the Marine Conservation Society, as well as East Lothian Councilrsquos Countryside Ranger Service.Pupils at the school have delivered presentations to local community councillors while a number of local businesses and organisations have signed up to the Bubbles Beat Balloons pledge.The campaign was part of the schoolrsquos work towards achieving gold status as a Rights Respecting School. Longniddry is the only primary school in East Lothian to hold Gold Right Respecting Schools status.The UNICEF UK award recognises the schoolrsquos work embedding childrenrsquos rights in its policy, practices and culture.Sheona Skinner, headteacher, said: ldquoIrsquom incredibly proud of Ellie using her pupil voice to continue our schoolrsquos campaign. Having the First Ministerrsquos support has widened awareness of the initiative and will hopefully encourage more people to become involved. It was a special occasion for Ellie and for everyone involved in Longniddry Primary School.

title: services-to-be-held-in-musselburgh-to-remember-well-known-nun
story: Sister Bernadette died peacefully in her nineties on March  at the Sisters of St Paulrsquos Convent and Care Home in Birmingham.She served St Annersquos Convent and Care Home in Windsor Gardens, Musselburgh, for  years, during which time she endeared herself to residents, relatives and staff.She was a familiar sight walking along the streets of Musselburgh and Portobello, as many of the nuns have done over the last  years since they arrived at St Annersquos to establish a rest home.Born in Burton-on-Trent, she joined the Sisters of Charity of St Paul the Apostle and taught in its schools in South Africa for more than  years.On herto England, she worked in parishes in Shropshire, Lancashire and London before moving to St Annersquos.She spent every spare minute knitting teddy bears, hats, scarves and gloves for children in Romanian schools and for St Annersquos summer fayre to raise funds for the residentsrsquo outings.Two years ago, due to failing health, Sister Bernadette retired to the convent and care home in Birmingham.A spokesperson for St Annersquos said: ldquoThe sisters wish to thank all the wonderful people in Musselburgh and Portobello who helped Sister Bernadette in her works of charity. She endeared herself to all she met by her gentle smile and kind greetings.ldquoAlso a huge thanks to all the bus drivers who made sure she ed home safely, especially in the wet and windy weather, and for whom she had a great respect and appreciation.The first Mass of Remembrance will be held at the chapel at St Annersquos this Sunday at .am. Entrance by Ashgrove. The second takes place at Our Lady of Loretto Church on Newbigging, Musselburgh, at .am on Wednesday. Everyone is invited to attend.

title: fourteen-musselburgh-area-projects-win-share-of-funding
story: This follows a public vote online and at a series of drop-in roadshows as part of the initiative organised by Musselburgh Area Partnership.The results of the poll were announced at an event in The Brunton on Saturday afternoon.The area partnership received pound, as part of the Scottish Governmentrsquos Community Choices Funding for   to give people a direct voice in how funds should be invested on priorities in their local areas as part of participatory budgeting .This was supplemented by funding from the area partnership, which allocates a budget from East Lothian Council to a iety of local priorities and initiatives.A total of  projects were shortlisted ndash  applications were received and an independent  considered them to ensure they met the guidelines and aims.The successful projects which will receive funding are:Iain Clark, area partnership chairman, said: ldquoYour Voice Your Choice  has been our second participatory budgeting initiative in our community. This has now seen  fantastic projects receive funding to help tackle poverty and reduce inequalities.ldquoI am extremely grateful to the community for voting and their support in deciding what projects they felt would make a dference. I am also extremely grateful to the many volunteers who worked tirelessly to make it all happen.ldquoMusselburgh Area Partnership will be excited to see the successful projects come to fruition and these projects will be monitored and evaluated over the next  months.Stuart Baxter, area partnership manager, said: ldquoI would also like to say a huge thank you to the community empowerment team at the Scottish Government, the Democratic Society Scotland and PB Scotland who offered help and advice throughout.ldquoA special thanks to all the groups who put forward bids and took part in the event and to all the community who took time to vote and help Musselburgh Area Partnership achieve its priority of helping to tackle poverty and inequalities.ldquoI would also like to acknowledge the financial support from East Lothian Council that underpins the work of the area partnership. This helped them secure the pound, external funding from the Scottish Governmentrsquos Community Choices Fund.

title: pavements-to-be-dug-up-over-next-nine-months-as-ultrafast-broadband-comes-to-musselburgh
story: The company says that this will help bring ldquoultrafast broadband speeds of up to Mbps ndash the fastest widely available speeds in the UK ndash to the area.Speaking at a meeting of Musselburgh and Inveresk Community Council last week, Eddie McGuigan, the companyrsquos community liaison officer, said that the project to lay fibre cable underground would get under way in mid-April.He said: ldquoWe will be in Musselburgh itself for the next eight or nine months, certainly until Christmas time.He added: ldquoThe idea is to give everyone the opportunity to get the cable.ldquoItrsquos a great thing for businesses and homes that use a lot of internet and wi-fi.ldquoThe downside to that is we are going to have to do some work on your pavements. We do about  metres a day, so wherever we are, we come and go quite quickly.He added that trenches would be created and high-pressure air used to blow a high fibre cable through.Mr McGuigan said that small cabinets, which are connection points for the network to residentsrsquo homes, would also be ldquodotted around areas.He stressed: ldquoWe donrsquot put them in corners or outside peoplersquos front windows. They canrsquot be in the line of sight of someone and we keep them away from driveways.ldquoAll the work we do is on adopted council land, so we speak to the council beforehand and get the notices in.ldquoIf we need to go into any private estates, shared drives and private roads, we seek way leave which is permission to go in there. If we donrsquot get that, we donrsquot go in.Small diggers will be used to carry out the work and soft areas will be dug up by hand.Mr McGuigan added: ldquoThe barriers will go upthere is a driveway and we will make sure itrsquos covered. We have ramps to go over, so everyone can get in and out.ldquoWe will dig up the pavement ndash unfortunately there will be a scar. We do it the same colour as the pavement. If itrsquos slabs, we will lt them up and put them back down. If itrsquos mono block, we have special mono blocking teams. If itrsquos just concrete, we use the same colour concrete. We will have multiple crews in multiple areas.He said that letters with his details would be sent out to local residents, adding: ldquoIf there is anyone on night sht, we will work round about that.Mr McGuigan said the work would start at the Fisherrow Harbour end of Musselburgh, with Wallyford the next phase, then Tranent and Port Seton.Information events will be held and a pop-up gazebo with information will also be located in the town centre.A company spokesman added: ldquoWith a Mbps connection, files, films and games become unbelievably quick to stream, download and upload.

title: first-dunbar-parkrun-to-be-held-this-weekend
story: The Lochend Woods Parkrun starts on Saturday morning, with runners covering a five-kilometre course in Hallhill.A trial took place on Saturday morning and Lynne Lewis, event director, was pleased to say things had gone smoothly ahead of the real thing starting at .am on Saturday.She said: ldquoThe parkrun trial happened in the most horrendous conditions.ldquoWe had  runners who braved the conditions and a lot were families, with mums and dads running with their children.ldquoWe tested all the kit on Saturday, tested the timer, uploading the times and that was all done on a test system.ldquoWe are expecting, hopefully, not too big a crowd ndash we could get  people running.Parkrun was formed in England more than  years ago by a group of friends who met each weekend for a jog.Until earlier this year, there were no parkrun events in East Lothian but Dunbar is set to join Meadowmill, near Tranent, in flying the flag for the county.Participants can either walk or jog the route, with a team of volunteers working hard for more than six months to see the event created.Mrs Lewis, who has taken part in more than  parkruns, said: ldquoIt is really about getting the message out there that parkrun is for everyone.The course starts at the running track outside Hallhill Sports Centre and is a figure-of-eight shape, comprising two laps of . kilometres.The course heads west away from the centre on tarmac paths around the sports pitches, then s towards the centre and heads into Lochend Woods, before ing towards the centre and repeating itself.Funding for the initiative has come from a number of local organisations, including the townrsquos running club, community council and Rotary club, as well as Viridor, EDF ndash Torness, Team East Lothian and Improve My Running.For more information, go to parkrun.org.uk lochendwoods

title: haddingtons-swimming-pool-to-close-for-nine-weeks-for-refurbishment
story: The pool and health suite at the townrsquos Aubigny Sports Centre is due to shut in April to allow operators enjoyleisure to update the pool hall, which dates back to the s.Essential maintenance and interior deacutecor works will be carried out at the sports centre, off Mill Wynd.Bill Axon, enjoyleisure general manager, said: ldquoWe are delighted to be working with our partners, East Lothian Council, to bring to fruition the upgrade of the pool hall at Aubigny Sports Centre for the benefit of our customers.ldquoIn a coastal county such as ours, being able to swim is a key le skill, as well as delivering numerous health and wellbeing benefits.ldquoAs East Lothianrsquos charitable sports provider, enjoyleisure is delighted to offer swimming opportunities across the county.ldquoIn order to deliver on our aim to inspire active communities, we realise our facilities have to be as inviting as possible. This refurbishment will truly revitalise the swimming pool within Haddington for the benefit of all.One of East Lothianrsquos original sports facilities, lsquoHaddington Swimming Poolrsquo, as it was first known, opened in September .The much-loved site consists of a four-lane swimming pool and East Lothianrsquos only dedicated infant pool.Currently, the facility welcomes about , bathers to the pool each week for swimming lessons, AquaFit classes, swimming club training, school and public use.enjoyleisure, which operates leisure centres in the county on behalf of the council, is working on plans to give the pool hall a facelt from its existing s facade.Currently, the work is scheduled to take place over a nine-week period from April .The refurbishment plans include the complete replacement of custom-fit ceiling window  and a new roof covering.Inside the pool hall, following a complete drain of both pools, a light and bright ceiling covering will replace the outdated wood cladding.A new energy-efficient lighting scheme will be fitted which it is hoped will transform the look and feel of the facility.Existing wall tiles will be replaced with wall liner  to complete the new look.While the pool and health suite will close for the work to take place, the rest of the centre, including the gym, dance studio, sports hall and cafe, will remain open.For more information on the refurbishment plans, go to enjoyleisure

title: tims-tales-leave-only-footprints
story: PRESSMENNAN Wood lies hidden at the foot of the northern slope of the fantastically named hill Deuchrie Dod, just a mile away from the beautul old village of Stenton. The wood surrounds a lake of the same name, which is actually a reservoir created  years ago.Pressmennan Lake is nearly km long and meanders through the wood, giving the appearance of a river rather than a loch. In summer, the lush canopy of trees which surround the lake can engulf the senses, and for a moment you can be fooled into thinking you are in the middle of an ancient forest.And in a sense, you are. The wood is a fragmentary remnant of the ancient oak wood which once covered most of our county. Records show it existed in medieval times, and Irsquom sure well before that.Much of it was felled, so tradition tells us, when the warship The Great Michael was built on the order of James IV around . This ship was famously constructed using the oak woods of Fe, but such was the size of the vessel that wood from where was also needed, including Pressmennan.Yet the wood seems to have survived, and in  the felling of trees here is said to have been stopped due to its importance as a habitat for the kingrsquos deer.It remains a place rich in wildle. Roe deer still roam free amidst the trees here. They are creatures of woodland magic, and native to these isles. They are small and nimble-footed, and will dart into the undergrowth at the sight or sound of approaching danger. They have short antlers and a tailless rear, which usually has a white patch. This is the part of the animal you most likely see, as it quickly bounds away from you.The wood is full of other wildle: owls and bats, hares and foxes, stoats and weasels, and, according to the Woodland Trust Scotland, who own and care for the wood, otters have also been seen in the lake. The birdle here is likewise rich, and there is a crescendo of song in the spring. The trust acquired the wood in  and is slowly restoring it to its natural character, planting oak and other native trees.We arrived at the wood last weekend, on a day of changeable weather, but laden with the promise of spring. There is a childrenrsquos map provided by the Woodland Trust and it proved a great hit for my kids, who followed the loch-side path looking for the features identied.These are wood carvings and sculptures made by artist Robin Wood. Part of the trail includes doors and windows in the trees which are said to be the homes of magical creatures called the Tootflits and Glingbobs.My children, well-versed in the folklore traditions of our county, know all about faeries, brownies, selkies, kelpies, witches and wizards. But Tootflits and Glingbobs were new to them, and to be honest myself as well.They are mythical creatures created by the artist and trust to provide a sense of wonder and adventure for children as they explore the wood. You can search for their homes and the wood sculptures along the way.And so we set off on our adventure of discovery. The path by the riverbank needs care with wee ones when wet, but it whispers magic. Ancient oak trees line the banks of the lake, their branches dipping into the water.These old trees were still leafless, biding their time for the arrival of spring proper. But they were a spine-tingling sight, a reminder of what once was here in abundance. But then, as we ventured deeper into the wood, we made a less pleasant discovery.Some people had decided it was a good idea to hammer coins into the sculptures, and even into the living trees. We found the homes of the Tootflits, and at their door was a pile of rusting coins which had clearly been left as a gt or good luck charm. Rusting coins also lay all around the base of the tree.I understand the desire to leave a gt or charm for a magical creature, but polluting and damaging nature with the ultimate symbol of materialism was, for me, horribly ironic.We removed what we could, and my daughter Skye searched for a more suitable gt. She found a small lsquofaerie cuprsquo, which was the cupule of an acorn, and placed it on the doorstep.ldquoThere, she said, with a sense of satisfaction.We continued our search but we found every sculpture defaced in the same way. One had actually collapsed due to the splintering and rot caused by the coins being hammered into it.The final sculpture was a frog on a log. It too was peppered with coins hammered into its body. In the universal measure of things, this damage was insignicant and perhaps even well-meaning, for I assume it was done by people who came to enjoy the wood and merely wanted to leave their charm here.But eventhere was no malice, it was a desecration. Then my heart tore as I watched my children scrape their fingers as they tried to pull the coins from the poor creature. But they were mostly rusted and too well-embedded.As we left the wood, I was reminded of a famous quote, attributed to the Native American chief Seattle: ldquoTake only memories and leave only footprints.The word lsquophotosrsquo is often used instead of memories but the message is the same, and now more powerful than ever. Itrsquos a worldwide issue ndash the desecration of natural sites by people who unthinkingly want to leave their mark. The coins that werenrsquot rusted we put in a charity box.The experience affected my daughter.ldquoCan you write about what we found, dad, and ask people not to do that  said Skye at bedtime. ldquoAsk them to find presents in nature, like faerie cups or stones or fallen branches or pine cones or berries, or even make a love heart shape in the ground. Faeries donrsquot like metal anyway or need money.And I promised her I would. As she slept, I kept my promise.

title: musselburgh-racecourse-business-continuing-to-be-conducted-in-private
story: Musselburgh Racing Associated Committeewas established by East Lothian Council last February after the British Horseracing Authority threatened to pull the coursersquos licence to race over concerns about its governance.Relations between members of predecessor body Musselburgh Joint Racing Committee were described as ldquofestering.It was made up of four East Lothian councillors and three members of Lothians Racing Syndicate , the latter representing racing interests.But the two factions were described in an independent report as having ldquoconsiderable mistrust, weariness, resentment and bitterness.Staff under the previous committee threatened to strike and there were claims of a lack of transparency surrounding their meetings and decisions.The independent report by Pinsent Mason was branded commercially sensitive by East Lothian Council, which refused to publish it until an investigation by the Information Commissioner led to a redacted version being made public.In February last year, the council replaced the old management committee with MRAC, giving the council a - majority over LRS.However, MRAC has held only four public meetings in council chambers in Haddington Town Hall since it was set up, with  of the  items of business on the agenda heard in private.On each occasion, the council has cited Local GovernmentAct , paragraph six, which allows it to exclude the public for ldquoinformation relating to the business affairs of particular persons other than the authority.East Lothian Council said that it ldquolooks to ensure that, as far as possible, committee matters are progressed in public.A spokesperson added: ldquoThe MRAC often considers matters in public session.ldquoAs with other committees, some reports may require to be held in private should they contain exempt information.Reports which have been withheld from the public include the current yearrsquos budget, financial reviews and racecourse general managerrsquos report.East Lothian Council is currently looking for a third-party operator to take over the running of the racecourse, which is on Common Good land.The hunt for a new operator is currently out to tender with hopes an appointment will be made before the end of this year.

title: prestonpans-shop-could-feature-on-bbc-show
story: Corner Shop Cook Off is coming to screens across the country to show off the importance of local convenience stores in Scotland.The new show is presented by actress and musician Clare Grogan, with winner of MasterChef The Professionals Gary Maclean as the resident chef.Each week, a prominent Scottish chef will guest star, going head to head with Gary, only using ingredients from a selected local convenience store from around the country.The Day-Today on Redburn Road in Prestonpans has been selected as a possible store to feature on the show and,it is picked, the BBC portable kitchen will be set up in Prestonpans Town Hall for the event next month.The BBC said that it wanted the local shop owner and the customers to be the judges, adding: ldquoThis means we can really get into the heart of towns all over Scotland and show how essential the local convenience store really isIf confirmed, Corner Shop Cook Off will be filmed on April  and  in Prestonpans Town Hall.

title: celebrations-as-prestonpans-charity-elcap-marks-its-30th-birthday
story: The Lighthouse Hub hosted the event with a buffet, guest speakers and local musicians.Even microphone problems and a broken slideshow couldnrsquot dampen the mood as the birthday bash opened with two pipers from Preston Lodge High School Pipe Band.Bette Francis, member of the ELCAP board, hosted the event, introducing the speakers: chief executive Paul White, ward councillor Fiona OrsquoDonnell, and lastly a moving testimony from fellow board member Kirstin Doherty.Paul White, who was appointed chief executive five months ago, started the talks by outlining the importance that ELCAP played within communities, a point that was reiterated by guest speaker Councillor Fiona OrsquoDonnell.The final speaker, Kirstin Doherty, a member of the ELCAP board, has been supported by the charity since . Her speech closed off the formal side of the event and she outlined how ELCAP had helped her move out of her parentsrsquo house, go on holiday and gain more independence.ldquoThey have helped me achieve more than I ever thought possible, she concluded.Kirstin, along with Ms OrsquoDonnell and Bette Francis, then proceeded to cut the cake to a chorus of lsquoHappy Birthdayrsquo from the guests.Attending the event was Linda Headland, the first chief executive of ELCAP in , a position she held until .ldquoItrsquos always good to know that you can leave something in good hands, she said.ldquoWhen ELCAP started, we always believed that it was about giving people a le, not just an existence, and that still stands to this day.ldquoItrsquos all about finding new ways to bring people in to the community.The charity, which is based in Prestonpans, will be hosting two other events this year to celebrate its th birthday, including one in June at the Scottish Parliament.

title: major-development-of-1500-new-homes-on-edge-of-musselburgh-approved
story: Today , East Lothian Council approved two planning applications by Persimmon Homes for more than  hectares of land surrounding Queen Margaret University, south of Musselburgh.The developments will include , houses across the site.Detailed planning permission for  of the new homes were approved for part of the site north of the A at Monktonhall.It is anticipated the majority of the remaining ,  homes will be built south of the A.There are also plans to build a new primary school south of the A for the future Craighall community where there will also be three full-size sports pitches and new lsquocycle superhighwaysrsquo created using a railway line which runs under the dual carriageway and a bridge.The masterplan for the land, which stretches from Stoneybank and Newcraighall in the north down past the village of Old Craighall , shows about  hectares of the land south of the A set aside for housing and the school, with a further  hectares for employment.North of the A, more than  hectares have been set aside for creating housing and an innovation park supporting research work at the university.Land has also been set aside for the possible expansion of Musselburgh Railway Station in future.Plans are also in place for a lsquomodiedrsquo junction from the A at the university which will have an underpass.Persimmon Homes East Scotland put in two separate planning applications ndash one for planning permission in principle for the whole -hectare site and a second for detailed planning permission for housing to the east of the university atMonktonhall.Robin Holder, representing the developers, said at a meeting of East Lothian Councilrsquos planning committee in Haddington on Tuesday that they believed the developments would be ldquovery positive for Musselburgh.Among the housing being built acrossthe entire site will be  affordable homes.Concerns were raised about the proximity of housing at Monktonhall to the A and the impact of noise on them.Councillor Jeremy Findlay said it appeared that the affordable housing was being built closest to the road, which is one of the main roads from Edinburgh to England.He said: ldquoI notice most of the houses next to the A are affordable houses, which to my mindsuggests the developers do not think they can sell private houses so close to it.However, it was pointed out there were other areas of the site also being used for affordable housing.Councillor John Williamson, ward member, said that the developments would bring ldquoimmense change to Musselburgh and people in the village of Old Craighall in particular.Discussions about catchment areas for families in the area will also be held in the future, after it was revealed that children living in the village would continue to attend Musselburghrsquos Campie Primary School one and a half miles away on the other side of the A, despite a new school being built on the edge of the village itself.Councillors approved both planning applications unanimously.

title: beer-garden-plan-at-haddington-pub-gets-the-go-ahead
story: Plans for the change at the rear of the Tyneside Tavern were approved by East Lothian Councilrsquos planning department.Planners had to weigh up the scheme against four letters of objection.According to the planning officerrsquos report, concerns focused on the idea that the beer garden would ldquogenerate harmful noise, disturbance and nuisance which will cause harm to the amenity of the neighbouring residential properties.A further concern noted: ldquoWith smoking being allowed outside, there is added health concern of passive smoke and also the danger of cigarettes being discarded over the adjoining walls, leading to the risk of fire in nearby sheds or the dry vegetation growing on the walls.However, the planning officer noted that anti-social behaviour was ldquooutwith the control of the applicant as iniduals are accountable for their own behaviour.The planning officerrsquos report on the application continued: ldquoThe issue of control and management of anti-social behaviour is a matter for the police to address in partnership with other agencies.The plans for the Poldrate business were submitted to the local authority last November and outlined that the beer garden would be open from am to .pm each day, with a capacity for  people.East Lothian Council has attached four conditions to the planning approval, limiting the use of the beer garden to between am and pm throughout the week.Similarly, public entertainment, amplied music, amplied vocals and live music are not allowed to be played in the beer garden.

title: big-turnout-for-dunbars-first-ever-parkrun
story: The non-competitive five-kilometre run takes place each Saturday morning, leaving from Hallhill Sports Centre.The Lochend Woods Parkrun is the second parkrun in East Lothian, following on the heels of a similar event at Meadowmill, near Tranent.Lynne Lewis, event director, was delighted with the turnout at the first event and said: ldquoIt was fantastic.ldquoThe weather was perfect, which was a big contrast to the week before.ldquoWe had  people there on Saturday and probably about  of them were parkrun tourists.ldquoThey came from dferent parts of Scotland to give it a whirl but the bulk of the runners, about , had never done a parkrun before and were totally new to the concept, which is really what it is all about.ldquoWe were delighted with that.Now, the organisers are hoping to build up a group of volunteers to help marshall the event, which attracted runners from school age right through to participants in their s.Although not a race, the quickest person over the course was local -year-old Corey Campbell, who finished in a time of ms.Parkrun was formed in England more than  years ago by a group of friends who met each weekend for a jog.Since then, the event has spread throughout the country, with more than  parkruns now taking place each weekend.Both of the East Lothian events get under way at .am each Saturday morning, with participants able to walk or jog the route.

title: idlewild-among-latest-acts-confirmed-for-fringe-by-the-sea
story: And there was further good news when RB legend Alexander OrsquoNeal, whose previously announced appearance had been in doubt due to contractual issues, was confirmed for the August - extravaganza.The organisers of the th annual Fringe by the Sea, which is again centred around Spiegeltents at the harbourside with pop-up venues across town, say they are bringing more Scottish musicians to the seaside.Idlewild, who release their eighth album next month and are led by frontman Roddy Woomble, will be treating the festival crowd to a live showcase of their acclaimed back catalogue, as well as brand new material from their new album Interview Music.On the same evening , Be Charlotte will be entrancing revellers with what has been described as a ldquoshimmering and powerful pop sound. The Dundee -year-old has already toured Europe, Asia and North America since finding her voice as a teenager with an acoustic guitar.Also, two Fringe By The Sea favourites are ing: Quattro MacJazz with their hot jazz and gospel and Hamish McGregor Plays Ball, Barber  Bilk.From America, Tim Eriksen will be at the North Berwick Fry with his combination of hair-raising vocals with inventive accompaniment on banjo, fiddle, guitar and bajo sexto.Bookworms will be queuing up to listen to Channel  Newsrsquo anchor Cathy Newman, who will be speaking about her book Bloody Brilliant Women.Elsewhere, TV presenter Dr Ben Garrod presents So You Think You Know About Dinosaurs He takes children and their parents on an exciting prehistoric adventure as dinosaur aficionado Ben explores the biggest, deadliest and weirdest predators that ever roamed the planet in this hit live interactive show.Another family show is Dr Jones Funny Bones with a fun look about the human body.Organisers say dozens more acts will be announced over the coming months, with the full programme set to offer more than  shows covering music, comedy, film, literature, family and kids, conversation, wellbeing and more.As previously reported in the Courier, Fred MacAulay, Alexander McCall Smith, Eddi Reader and Christine Bovill are among the household names already confirmed.North Berwickrsquos Scottish Seabird Centre will also present a soon-to-be-announced programme of conservation and environmental events.There will also be literary shows at North Berwick Library and outdoor action taking locals and visitors out and about in East Lothian.Festival co-director Niall Middleton said: ldquoWersquore really looking forward to seeing all the acts we have programmed so far. Performers love the opportunity to come to North Berwick and the word is out that this is definitely a cool festival in which to be involved.And he added: ldquoWe are delighted that tickets for Alexander OrsquoNealrsquos performance on August  are now on sale. We know from the flood of enquiries we had following our initial announcement that this will be one of the most popular shows at Fringe by the Sea this summer.Anyone interested in volunteering at the festival should email info@fringebytheseaTo buy tickets, go to www.fringebytheseaActs announced so far include: Friday, August : Fred MacAulay Honey Farm. Saturday, August : MALKA Moishersquos Bagel The Cuban Brothers. Sunday, August : James Brown Is Annie Christine Bovill Alexander OrsquoNeal. Monday, August : Doug Allan. Tuesday, August : Old Blind Dogs. Wednesday, August : Val McDermid in lunchtime conversation Blue Rose Code. Wednesday, August : Alexander McCall Smith in lunchtime conversation Dean Owens and the Celtabilly Allstars. Friday, August : Be Charlotte Idlewild. Saturday, August : Cathy Newman Dr Ben Garrod Rubian Eddi Reader.

title: east-lothian-council-lar-housing-rejected
story: Housing charity LAR had applied to build four houses and  flats on the land, which is designated for business use, in Prestonpans but has failed to find an employer to take it on.Despite a personal plea from the charityrsquos chief executive and an admission that East Lothian Council had tried to buy the site for housing itself just two years ago, the affordable housing bid was rejected at a meeting of the councilrsquos planning committee on Tuesday.The decision came despite LAR revealing it had invested pound, in preparing plans for the site after it was told the council would consider a change of use.Chief executive Ann Leslie told the committee that out of  homes built or under construction by the charity since it began,  had been in East Lothian and there were currently  people on its waiting list to move into one in the county.And she revealed the charity has been considering moving its base to East Lothian.She said: ldquoWe are very keen to support East Lothian as much as we are able to bring as many affordable homes as we can. There is a big waiting list in the county and we hope to open a base here.But planning officers urged councillors to reject LARrsquos proposals, regardless of their own efforts to build housing there two years ago.Iain McFarlane, head of planning, said that two years ago the council did not have its Local Development Plan approved and faced a shortage of land for affordable housing.Now the plan had been adopted, he said there was sufficient land supply for the next five years.He said allowing housing on the site would set an ldquoundesirable precedent, adding it would be ldquoselling our employment plans down the river.Councillor Kenny McLeod, committee member, said he was ldquodeeply uncomfortable about refusing planning permission on a site the council had tried to develop in the same way two years ago.At the time, council officers said the landowner rejected their pound, offer as too low.Robin Holder, representing LAR at the meeting, said the council had given written reassurance it would consider the site, which has lain empty since , for housing.He rejected claims that approving the plans would set a precedent, saying: ldquoThis is a small area, this site is a quarter of one per cent of land identied for industrial use in East Lothian. The site has been vacant for many years and the evidence suggests it will remain so.But Councillor Norman Hampshire said: ldquoI cannot support the application: it would send a message to other owners of land designated for business use.The committee rejected the planning application by six votes to three.Following the meeting, Ms Leslie said: ldquoNaturally we are disappointed at the decision and are considering whether to appeal against it.ldquoWe have worked very closely with East Lothian Council over the last three years on a number of projects to enhance the provision of good-quality affordable homes in the area and have enjoyed a very positive working relationship with them.ldquoOur proposal for Prestonpans was a design and build project for  homes, very similar to our recently completed development at the disused site of the former boatyard in Cockenzie. This proved to be extremely popular and was vastly oversubscribed, so there is an urgent need for homes like ours.ldquoWe understand that this site in Prestonpans had been earmarked for commercial use but, in the absence of any confirmed interest, we had hoped that our plans, which would enhance the local environment and provide much-needed affordable housing, would have been supported.

title: woman-was-five-and-a-half-times-over-drink-drive-limit-in-prestonpans
story: Gayle Duffy has been banned for  months after she was caught with mcg of alcohol in ml of breath at High Street, Prestonpans.The legal limit is just mcg.Duffy, of Clark Avenue, was also sentenced to a -day restriction of liberty order meaning she must stay within her home address between pm and am for the duration of the order.The -year-old had previously admitted the offence and she was sentenced at Edinburgh Sherf Court last Wednesday.Duffy admitted drink-driving on February .

title: east-lothian-residents-urged-to-switch-off-for-earth-hour
story: Earth Hour encourages people to turn off all non-essential lighting for one hour and is being supported by East Lothian Council.Every year, millions of people participate in the WWF global movement to raise awareness about climate change and the human impact on the earth.Major landmarks such as the Efel Tower, Buckingham Palace, Edinburgh Castle and the Sydney Opera House switch off all lights and visual displays run by electricity for the hour.Earth Hour takes place between pm and pm tomorrow.

title: asbo-bans-musselburgh-woman-from-abusive-behaviour
story: The ASBO was granted against Vivienne Stewart, , of Stoneybank Gardens South, following an application to Edinburgh Sherf Court by East Lothian Council.The court was presented with details of the alleged anti-social behaviour of Ms Stewart, which included shouting and swearing, excessive noise and reports of late-night disturbances.The terms of the ASBO ban her from behaving in a way that causes or is likely to cause alarm or distress to others, including playing a radio, TV or other sound-producing devices at anti-social levels, as well as shouting, swearing or using threatening, intimidating, aggressive or abusive language or behaviour within her home.A council spokesperson said: ldquoEast Lothian Council, with the support of Police Scotland, will not hesitate in taking robust action against those whose behaviour causes alarm and distress to others.

title: msp-hopeful-of-vastly-improved-service-at-musselburgh-gp-surgery
story: The group was highlighted by Colin Beattie, MSP for Midlothian North and Musselburgh, who recently met Jeane Freeman MSP, Cabinet Secretary for Health and Sport, following ldquooverwhelming public concern regarding the serious lack of appointments to see a doctor and the poor level of service offered by the practice.Mr Beattie stated that a spokesperson from the medical practice, which is based at Musselburgh Primary Care Centre, indicated that ldquoimprovements in the way patients are being cared for in Musselburgh are in the process of being made.Early evaluation of the way services were being delivered since the launch of the Collaborative Working for Immediate Care service ndash run by East Lothian Health and Social Care Partnershipand the merged Eskbridge and Riverside Medical Practices ndash demonstrated that patients who previously would have seen a GP were now seeing the right clinician at the right time for their specic needs.The new service, developed in partnership by Riverside, NHS  and ELHSCP, ensured that urgent care was dealt with on the same day and patients should have ldquono anxieties about being seen by the right professional at the right time.Through this new way of delivering patient care, it not only provided an increase in the number of patient appointments with practice GPs and other healthcare professionals, but also provided an increase in appointmentfor patients with complex needs.A recent survey conducted within the practice demonstrated that more than half of patients agreed that they did not always need to see a GP.Work is also under way by ELHSCP to implement a new telephone and IT system that will support call demand into the practice.The importance of patient involvement in getting services right is ldquovery much recognised by the practice, which is encouraging residents to get involved with the Patient Participation Group.Speaking after meeting with the Cabinet Secretary, Mr Beattie said: ldquoI would like to assure all of my constituents that patient care is of paramount importance and that all agencies involved in the new way services are being delivered within Musselburgh Primary Care Centre are focused on delivering the best care possible.ldquoRiverside Medical Practice is working with other organisations to ensure that improvements are made and I would encourage anyone with any issues regarding the practice to get in touch with them and become involved with the patient participation group.ldquoI am hopeful that the improvements being made by the organisations will be seen by patients and a vastly improved service will be delivered.ldquoI will continue to closely monitor the future performance of the practice and ask patients to keep me advised on whether the improvements are working.

title: seatbelt-embarrassment-spurs-on-musselburgh-couple-to-big-weight-loss
story: Derek Melon, , a customer services advisor, and his we Carole, , a mortgage advisor, of James Street, are both feeling ldquofantastic after their bumper weight loss, which was sparked by a holiday to Florida.Derek has dropped five stones from st lbs to st lbs, and Carole, who weighed in at st lbs, lost four-and-a-half stones to get to st lbs since they joined Weight Watchers in June last year.Their journey started after the couple, who have a teenage son, booked a holiday to Florida.Carole said: ldquoI was so excited but the plane journey going left me feeling humiliated and not happy as I had to request a seatbelt extension as I could not fasten the original seatbelt. Thankfully no one heard me asking for it but the embarrassment of having to ask was enough to spur me on.ldquoAt this point, on what should have been an exciting time, I was left feeling down, and it was then that I decided that it was time to lose weight.ldquoNever again did I want to be in that position of asking for an extension. The next time I was flying I wanted to be able to buckle up like any other person.ldquoWhen I ed, I decided to join Weight Watchers at Musselburgh Hope Church, and it was the best decision I have ever made.ldquoI have now lost more than four-and-a-half stones and feel fantastic. I find the Weight Watchers app amazing as its so easy to use and being able to track is really simple and motivating.ldquoI am a very fussy eater, and, on the plan, I can still have a treatI want. This makes le easy and no one really knows you are on a healthy eating plan as I can eat just like everyone .ldquoEverything about the Freestyle plan just suits me, and, even though I donrsquot eat meat or fish, I can still eat a lot of what I like.ldquoThe weekly workshops are very motivational and I love going. My wellness coach, Lisa Stewart, is so supportive, as well as all the other members.ldquoNow I can make the right choices, walk more and shop for clothes that I would never have been able to buy before. Clothes shopping has also become really enjoyable and less expensive as I no longer need to buy a size  but a rather smaller size .ldquoWalking has now become easier as I used to get breathless but this does not happen now. I have the motivation to keep going even when Irsquove put weight on as Irsquom not perfect.Derek was inspired to lose weight by Carole, saying: ldquoMy we joined Weight Watchers and her initial weight loss was inspiring. I knew I had to lose weight but I just never had the motivation to do anything about it.ldquoMy we was looking amazing and it was then that I knew it was time for me to get on the Weight Watchers wagon. Irsquom so glad I joined with Carole as I find it easy to follow.ldquoI can still eat my favourite snacks ndash crisps ndash which is something I was not prepared to give up. Thankfully I can enjoy these and still lose weight.ldquoDoing the Freestyle plan with Carole is really good although we do not always eat the same foods. The choice of foods that we can enjoy and eat means both us can enjoy what we want.ldquoThe support from the coach Lisa is fantastic and sometimes Irsquom the only male who stays for the weekly talk. This does not phase me as my weight loss is too important and everyone is really friendly. Even when my we canrsquot make it, I go on my own. Men should not be afraid of joining as Irsquove had a fantastic weight loss.ldquoMy food choices are now better and I pay more attention to what I eat. We both used to eat things like large bars of chocolate, deep-pan pizzas, lots of bread and cheese. There was no thought to what we were eating.ldquoWe now eat better with lots of fresh fruit and veg, and have more thought in what we are preparing and eating and are both enjoying our food much better.He added: ldquoA big tick to myself is that I can now buy jeans in Primark ndash something I was not able to do before. It sounds silly but being able to go and buy a  waist instead of a -inch waist just makes me smile. My top size used to be an XXXL but can now buy a size XL L, so itrsquos quite clear why I enjoy buying new clothes.

title: tims-tales-the-magic-bracelet
story: THE origins of this tale came a while ago after a leg came off my daughter Manjarsquos favourite baby doll.She had been given the doll by her grandmother when she was only two years old. She called it Big Baby.She decided it was a girl and it became her favourite doll. It was soft and easy to cuddle, and Manja would take it with her everywhere.After years of being carried, played with and subjected to all manner of pampering with nail polish and make-up, the condition of the doll began to deteriorate.Then one day, Big Babyrsquos right leg came off! The seam holding the leg had torn and repeated repairs failed.At that time, I suggested we could replace her. But my daughter looked at me in horror: ldquoJust because she has one leg doesnrsquot mean I love her less.I remember being stung by my own insensitivity. Big Baby was not just an old doll, and I should have known that.Manja was six then. She is near  now. She has obviously grown in her games and play, yet Big Baby remains an important part of the family. But the loss of her dollrsquos leg led Manja into talking about disability. Over the years, it was a topic she wouldto when she was playing with her. She adapted clothes for Big Baby and refused to treat her as broken, or any less a doll.Then, recently, during one our story-making sessions together, she suddenly came up with this tale. We then wrote it down. I helped her with spelling and some phrases, but otherwise this is all her work and idea.I agree that children need to be taught empathy, but they often soon get it in ways adults forget, as I did. The discrimination and prejudice we encounter is taught by adults to children. Butwe listen to our children, they can often be the best teachers of understanding and empathy for us all.So here is Manjarsquos tale, which she titled The Magic Bracelet:Once there was an old man who had a foot which wouldnrsquot work and so he had dficulty walking.He had to use crutches and people said he was disabled, and because of this nobody would give him a job.So to get some money he would sit by the roadside and make porridge. Hersquod sell bowls of it to people who were walking by on their way to work. He told them that porridge was healthy and the best breakfast, which is true of course.So people would give him a penny for a bowl of his delicious porridge. That way he made some money.One day, while he was making his porridge, a young girl came and told him she would love to have a bowl of porridge but she had no money. The porridge maker gave the girl a kind smile.ldquoNever mind, he said, ldquoI always make extra just in case itrsquos needed.He handed her a bowl of porridge and she sat down and ate it. She was very hungry.As she gave the porridge-maker the bowl back, she noticed his crutches leaning against the wall.ldquoWhy do you have crutches  asked the girl.The porridge-maker looked sad and told her that he couldnrsquot walk very well because of his foot that wonrsquot work. He explained he needed his crutches to walk.The girl thought for a moment and smiled at the porridge-maker.ldquoI have a friend who can help you so you wonrsquot be disabled anymore, she said. The old man smiled at her, but this time it was a sad smile.ldquoThat is very kind of you, he said to the girl, ldquobut the doctors have told me that there is nothing that can be done to fix my foot, so I will be disabled for the rest of my le.ldquoPlease meet my friend, asked the girl. So the porridge-maker agreed.The girl helped him up and he walked slowly with his crutches with her. She took him to a beach.ldquoWait here, Irsquoll go get my friend, said the girl. The old man sat on the sand and waited for a long time. Eventually the girl ed.ldquoHere, she said, ldquotake my hand and Irsquoll take you to my friend. But first you must wear this shell bracelet.It was a beautul bracelet, made from dferent shells. He put it around his wrist.The porridge-maker went to pick up the crutches but the girl said: ldquoNo, leave them there, you will not need them.ldquoBut I canrsquot walk without them, he said. The girl just smiled and said: ldquoTrust me. So he did.She held his hand and slowly led him into the sea.He was hobbling at first, but the sea rose over his legs and his body got lighter in the water. Soon he was up to his waist in water.ldquoI cannot swim, said the porridge-maker, now feeling worried.ldquoTrust me, said the girl, ldquoI am wearing a bracelet as well, so we will e in together.So he trusted her and he ed into the water. Suddenly, he realised that there was some magic happening because he could breathe under the water. And he wasnrsquot cold or afraid.Then he saw the girlrsquos friend. She was a mermaid. ldquoWelcome, said the mermaid.ldquoYou see, said the girl, ldquoI told you my friend could help. The bracelet is magic, it gives you the ability to be like a mermaid and swim under the sea.The porridge-maker swam perfectly under the sea. He was not disabled under the sea. He could swim fast and he did circles and back flips. He smiled at the girl, this time a happy smile.ldquoThank you, he said. She smiled a happy smile back: ldquoMy friend said you can keep the bracelet and use it as often as you want.And so he did. And he realised it wasnrsquot his foot which made him feel disabled, but other people being unkind and making fun of him or treating him as useless.He still couldnrsquot walk well, but he knew he could breathe and swim under the water like a mermaid, while those who made fun of him couldnrsquot. And he could make the most delicious porridge ever. He understood now that although he had a disability, he was not disabled.

title: wallyfords-new-public-library-based-in-school-to-open
story: The facility has been provided as part of the new Wallyford Primary School project at Futures Way to meet the demands of major new house building in the area.The library bears the name of Margaret Oliphant, a th-century writer from Wallyford.Born on April , , she died on June , .Alister Hadden, chairman of Wallyford Community Council, has given support about local historical events which are reflected in the new building.A spokesperson for East Lothian Council said: "The community library has been named the Margaret Oliphant Library."The graphics on the internal windows, the old ship wheel from the former school badge and the external brickwork reflect aspects of Wallyfordrsquos history."This will be further developed in partnership with the community council and library over time."The library, which replaces the former library at Faside Buildings, has a separate entrance and exit when open for the public on: Monday and Tuesday, pm to pm Thursday, pm to pm Friday, am to pm and pm to pm Saturday, am to pm. The library is closed on Wednesdays.Outwith these hours, the library is available for the school to use either through class visits or for iniduals to use. Library staff are available to arrange activities such as book clubs or how to research projects.This is a "unique situation" for East Lothian as, until now, there have been separate staffed school libraries in the secondary schools and public libraries in the community.

title: new-tenants-take-over-cafe-at-dunbars-lauderdale-park
story: Bev Anderson and John Semple, , signed the lease for the cafe in Lauderdale Park last week and are already busy working to get the business open for around Easter.The couple run the Wishing Tree Play Cafe on Musselburgh High Street, which they will operate alongside the Dunbar business, named Wishing Tree... By The Sea.Bev said: ldquoWe have had the Wishing Tree coming up for four years.ldquoI actually had signed the lease four years ago for the Wishing Tree and three weeks later the lease came up on [Lauderdale Park].ldquoAt that stage, I did not think I was in a position to do it.ldquoI have been coming to Dunbar for a long number of years and had a caravan at Pease Bay.ldquoWe moved to the area and I used to take my daughters to the park. We used to play there all the time and go to the cafe and I always loved the setting and thought it had so much potential.Now, with the Wishing Tree up and running, Bev and husband John, of the townrsquos Countess Road, are excitedly working on transforming the building.A takeaway hatch is being installed, with plans for a vintage ice cream bike and ice cream to be sold.Bev, who hopes to create at least three jobs in Dunbar, said: ldquoThe reality is it is going to be fresh home-baking and local produce.ldquoWe are targeting as much local produce as we can and there are a lot of good things going on in the area.ldquoThere will be fresh homemade salads, the healthy side of things, but there will be sweets and treats as well.The business hopes to be open in time for the European Stone Stacking Championships, which takes place in the town on April  and .Bev, , will run the cafe and was keen to get involved in community events, with the possibility of food markets also being considered.The business will be open five days a week during term time and throughout the week during the holidays.Bev said: ldquoThere are a lot of local events in Dunbar.ldquoThere is Civic Week and other things and we are really keen to be part of the existing programme. There is so much going on in Dunbar and we want to be adding wee things in the future.

title: businesses-in-north-berwick-urged-to-let-people-use-their-toilet
story: The nearest public toilets to the town centre are located at the entrance to the Imperial Car Park, off Quality Street.However, anyone at the other end of High Street, particularly those heading to the townrsquos train station, have nowhere to lsquospend a pennyrsquo.Now, North Berwick Coastal Area Partnershiprsquos lsquoOn the Move grouprsquo has launched an initiative to encourage businesses on High Street and surrounding roads to make their facilities available.Premises can display a signthat simply says: ldquoYoursquore welcome to use our toilet.Hilary Smith, chairwoman of the On The Move group, was hopeful businesses would sign up to the scheme.She said: ldquoWe are delighted at the support local businesses have offered to this initiative.ldquoThe lack of toilets at our train station has been a long-running concern. We have not taken our eye off that problem, but this project ensures that people wonrsquot get caught short!One of those signing up to the scheme is the townrsquos Westgate Gallery.Roy Symon, from the business, said: ldquoWe are very pleased to share our facilities and place a sign in our window.ldquoWe want to help our visitors feel welcome and enjoy what beautul North Berwick has to offer.For more information, email nbc-ap@eastlothian.gov.uk

title: poppy-smith-close-to-pool-dream
story: Poppy Smith has been unable to swim at county leisure centres for three years after taking unwell in September .The youngster, from Gullane, was initially suffering from cold-like symptoms but woke the next morning unable to swallow or move her arm.She was diagnosed with a rare condition called acute flaccid myelitis, which damages nerves in the spinal cord.Now, the eight-year-old is continuing her recovery after undergoing an operation at Edinburghrsquos Royal Hospital for Sick Children.Her mum Laura told the Courier: ldquoUnfortunately Poppy had a tough winter with viral illnesses that affected her breathing.ldquoShe had to be hospitalised in November with pneumonia and lung collapse, and go back to having help with her breathing overnight.ldquoShe now has a non-invasive ventilator [nasal mask] to help her and she has been in great health since the start of the year. We are hoping that as she grows and her chest muscles get stronger, we can try again without the ventilator support.ldquoThe great thing about the non-invasive ventilation is that she doesnrsquot need her tracheostomy [tube in her neck] anymore and she has recently had an operation to close up the stoma [hole] in her neck and airway.ldquoThe operation went really well and Poppy is delighted with how it looks as she was always very self-conscious about the tracheostomy.ldquoNow that the stoma is closed, she is able to speak more loudly and even sing!ldquoOnce she has been given the all clear that it has healed well, she will be able to go in water.ldquoShe hasnrsquot been able to swim properly for three years and is very excited to be able to do this again!The community got behind the youngster, who is in P at the villagersquos primary school, with a series of fundraisers, collecting more than pound,.Some of the money, as well as a grant from the Jude Brady Foundation, was used to buy a hydrotherapy pool.Hydrotherapy could benefit the youngster but, unfortunately, there is only limited provision through the NHS and it involves travelling some distance.Poppyrsquos mum added: ldquoWe will then be able to do more hydrotherapy exercises with her in the pool that the Gullane community fundraised for.ldquoWe hope that this will help to strengthen the muscles in her core and arms.Last year, the youngster was part of a crowd of more than , at the Falkirk Stadium to see pop stars Little Mix.Poppy, joined by her elder sister Jessica, was able to meet band members Perrie Edwards, Jesy Nelson, Jade Thirlwall and Leigh-Anne Pinnock, famous for hits such as Black Magic, Shout Out To My Ex and Cannonball.

title: bring-back-your-bottles-for-cash
story: Ferhan Ashiq, store owner of Day-Today on Redburn Road, is visiting schools in the area to engage children in the recycling and the depositscheme he is championing.The scheme is an initiative whereby a deposit is paid by the consumer on certain recyclable items, which can be redeemed when the empty vessel is ed to the store.Ferhan said: ldquoIrsquove been prompted to take action because of my two young children ndash climate change will impact them more than me, so I want to do whatever I can to make a dference.ldquoThe community already does beach cleans every few weeks, and now I hope this new initiative will help to stop the materials ending up there in the first place.ldquoThe scheme will be rolled out across Scotland anyway, so itrsquos better for people that local businesses get on board now and get used to using the machines and see the positive effect that they can have on a community.

title: plans-to-extend-ross-high-school-revealed
story: The proposals were recently presented to members of the school community by project team FES and Hub South East to allow the opportunity to view and comment on them before a planning application is submitted to East Lothian Council.The plans include two major components, the first being new sports facilities including a new games hall with two badminton courts and a new changing village with inidual cubical unisex changing rooms.The second involves a new teaching block with  new classrooms, housing languages, art, ICT and a social area with a small canteen.Paul Reynolds, headteacher, said: ldquoThis is what is best for the school to provide learning, safety and comfort.ldquoWe will work hard to keep the school running through the building of the extension and the result will be worth it. Everyone in the school and the surrounding area will feel the benefit.There will also be internal work on the current building that will be incorporated into the plans, including new drama studios and new toilets.ldquoThe new toilets are in some ways most important, said Mr Reynolds. ldquoIt is important to the school to make toilets safe and comfortable places.ldquoLike the new dressing rooms, the toilets will be inidual floor-to-ceiling cubicles with the potential to be unisex, and some will be.ldquoWhether they all will be is a question that will be put to students and parents when they are built.Ross High will soon hit its capacity of pupils, with  first years set to start next school year, meaning the school could be home to , students over the next few years.Ward councillor Fiona Dugdale said: ldquoIrsquom delighted that the plans are going ahead. The feedback I have heardfrom parents, carers and the school has been terric, and the extension will support the learning experience of the young people.The council set aside pound million out of its five-year capital improvement budget in February for the work, which will take about a year.A council spokesperson said: ldquoWe will now take on board the feedback received during the consultation to bring forward a planning application.

title: sprint-star-maria-lyle-backing-initiative
story: World and European champion Maria linked up with Scott Hastings to launch Support in Mind Scotlandrsquos  Streets Challenge.Participants are encouraged to get creative by devising their own route before walking, running or cycling  streets in their community any time between April  and World Mental Health Day on October .Nineteen-year-old Maria, from Dunbar, has courageously talked about her own mental health struggles in the past and is passionate about raising awareness and encouraging others to seek helpor when they need it.Support in Mind Scotland provide services and support to more than , people affected by mental ill health each week.European champion and Commonwealth Games medallist Lyle, fresh from winning double gold in the m and m at the World Para Athletics Grand Prix in Dubai, said: ldquoMental health is a cause close to my heart and I am delighted to be able to help Support in Mind Scotland with this great initiative, which helps people stay physically active.ldquoI know from my own experience that mental ill health affects many of us, but it is reassuring that there are charities around like Support in Mind Scotland to offer expert help and support where and when it is needed.ldquoThe  Streets Challenge will further help raise awareness of mental health issues. It is a simple and fun way for people to get out and explore their communities, either on their own or as part of a group.Para-athlete Maria, who has diplegic cerebral palsy, has represented Scotland at the Commonwealth Games and Great Britain at the Paralympics.Ahead of last yearrsquos European Championships, the teenager revealed her own mental health struggles to her mum, Susan.She was diagnosed with anxiety and recently thanked her mum, saying: ldquoIn my darkest moment, my mum was there for me. She was the one who listened for hours. She was the one who hugged me.ldquoFrom that day, my mum and my immediate family have supported me. They have made me realise that there is more to le than running.

title: knox-academy-goes-green-for-week-of-events
story: Knox Academy held its third annual eco-week, with ious presentations given to all year groups.Modern languages teacher Jessica Laudi, the eco-committee and the green team planned events to get pupils to think about how change is essential to overcome environmental problems.The modern languages teacher and some S pupils ran a plastic-free tutorial at lunchtime, attended by students and staff.Miss Laudi said: ldquoWe talked about plastic-free alternatives like shampoo bars, solid facial cleansers, solid moisturisers, toothpaste tabs, coconut oil, lip balms and more.ldquoOn the Tuesday, we welcomed Lil, an East Lothian-based eco-shop, to Knox Academy at lunchtime and during our S parentsrsquo night. Students, staff, and parents had the opportunity to explore and purchase eco-friendly items like reusable straws, shampoo bars, reusable water bottles, reusable coffee cups and even compostable parchment paper.ldquoOn the Wednesday, the green team did its usual collection of recycling from classrooms.P pupils from St Maryrsquos Primary School and Yester Primary School in Gford took part in eco-themed events, including eco-Pictionary, a drama scenario about bees, climate change trivia and a recycling sorting task.Sue Cook, headteacher at Knox, said: ldquoIt was great to receive positive feedback from some P parents about how much their children had enjoyed these activities, led by the pupils.

title: fiona-veerman-and-friends-aiming-to-jet-off-with-rylan-clark-neal-to-mallorca
story: The huge online giveaway by holiday firm Jetholidays attracted thousands of entries ndash and Fiona Veerman has made it to the final nine.Fiona, , entered the company by describing her perfect lsquoparty planersquo: an lsquoicon partyrsquo where guests dress as their favourite icons and enjoy an srsquo music playlist.Voting closes tomorrowat pm, with the winner announced the following day.The winner will spend a VIP weekend on the Balearic island later this month - with  of their chosen friends and family!Fiona, whose family run pet supplies and hardware shop Veermanrsquos, just off Tranent High Street, said she created her plane lsquoHappy Landingrsquo for her family.The winning  guests will be joined by TV celebrity Rylan Clark-Neal.ldquoWho doesnrsquot want a free weekend party in the sun with Rylan Clark as the host  added Fiona.ldquoHe looks such amazing fun to be around."To vote for Fiona, visit partyplane.jetholidays and click on Happy Landing.

title: creche-closure-date-announced-for-enjoyleisure-centres
story: Enjoyleisure, which runs sports centres, swimming pools, sports pitches and two golf courses across the county, announced last month that creches would be closing following a drop in funding.Now, the charity has confirmed that the service will be withdrawn from noon on April .Bill Axon, general manager of enjoyleisure, said: ldquoI genuinely appreciate how disappointing such decisions can be for certain patrons, however, I can assure our customers and future customers, the Board of enjoy and myself are committed to ensuring the ongoing provision of sport, leisure and fun activities across East Lothian for many years to come.A petition, signed by nearly , people, was launched by a group of concerned parents under the banner lsquoChildren and Families of East Lothianrsquo following the announcement the creches would be closing.A group of parents contacted Iain Gray, MSP for East Lothian, about the issue and met with representatives from enjoyleisure in a bid to see the decision reversed.Mum-of-four Sarah Brunton was among those campaigning for the facilities to remain in place.She regularly uses the sports centres in Haddington, North Berwick and Dunbar and was disappointed to hear a date had now been set.And she warned the decision could lead to people cancelling their memberships.She said: ldquoBasically, the people I have spoken to, each and every one of us, will have to withdraw our membership."We have not got any other option.Over the past  years, since enjoyleisurersquos creation, the cregraveche service has been retained for the benefit of customers, despite operating at a shortfall.However, as user numbers continued to decline year upon year, the subsequent financial deficit increased the strain on the rest of the organisation.A spokeswoman for the group said ldquostrict adult to child ratios and current charging requirements reduce enjoyleisurersquos capacity of increasing income for this service, and at existing user levels, it is not possible to retain this provision at an affordable cost to customers.With ldquosubstantial increases in business operational costs and a drop in council funding, enjoyleisure took the decision to ldquore-evaluate its current financial and operational position in order to ensure the long-term sustainability and viability of the whole organisation.Mr Axon told the Courier: ldquoI also recognise the efforts of the lsquoChildren and Families of East Lothianrsquo, with whom I have met with personally, to outline our current position and provide further detail to the wider context within which has ultimately forced us into making these decisions.The general manager also described enjoyleisure staff as ldquoa credit to themselves.He added: ldquoWe would additionally like to take this opportunity to thank our customers and staff for their continued support and loyalty.ldquoAs a local charitable organisation, we cannot survive without your backing, and we are incredibly grateful for this.ldquoAs East Lothianrsquos sports and leisure charity, we work closely with East Lothian Council, local sports clubs and the wider community to maintain affordable access to safe and fit for purpose facilities to the best of our ability.ldquoThis, even though the financial environment within which we operate is currently exceptionally dficult, remains a principal objective.ldquoLikewise, to retain sport and leisure facilities in all our major towns, which allows for easy, local access for all our communities.
