title: revealed-scotlands-happiest-place-to-live-is-near-glasgow
story: Research for Royal Mail analysed eight separate measures thought to be linked to happiness, including le expectancy, crime levels and earnings.The council area south-west of Glasgow topped the Scottish list, with its position cemented by a high placing in the earnings index.Top  happiest places to liveThe area scored in the th percentile across all local authorities in the UK for income, Royal Mail said.East Dunbartonshire came second in the Scottish study after boasting low levels of crime and good access to health services.Aberdeenshire completed the top three, also scoring highly for health services.Stirling, in fourth place, was found to have a comparatively good level of earnings relative to other local authorities in Scotland.The Scottish Borders secured the next position on the list with the second lowest level of crime in Scotland, followed closely by Midlothian and East Lothian.Highlandand the Shetland Islandswere the two northernmost local authorities on the top  list.Highland had the joint highest score for reported well-being across the UK, while the Shetland Islandsrsquo low crime rate and low deprivation levels edged it past other areas.South Ayrshire finished in ninth position with its strong performance in access to local services.Winchester was declared the happiest place to live in the UK.A Royal Mail spokeswoman said: ldquoThis new study takes a look at the areas across the UK sparking the most joy.ldquoFor people across the UK looking to live in or visit the happiest places, there are plenty to choose from.Royal Mail commissioned Cebr to construct the happiness indexearlier this year.The eight measures studied were reported personal well-being, le expectancy, earnings, inequality, carbon emissions, crime, deprivation and access to health services.

title: slimming-world-weight-loss-wonder-sheds-10-stone-to-achieve-london-marathon-dream
story: Gail Tennant, , from Airdrie joined the Airdre Slimming World group in February  weighing more than st. Now she will be representing Slimming World in their national team of  slimmers from across the UK and Ireland on April th . This yearrsquos team will be the official golden Slimming World marathon team, as the organisation celebrates its th birthday year.Collectively, the team have lost more than st and will be running to raise money for Cancer Research UK and the Irish Cancer Society. The team aim to increase awareness of how keeping a healthy weight can reduce the risk of developing some types of cancer.Supporting the cancer charities is particularly important to Gail as she has seen her dad battle the disease.When first Gail joined the Airdrie Slimming World she had been running for around nine months, however struggled to get reach a certain distance with her weight and poor diet taking its toll. When she joined Slimming World, however, she found she could eat to fuel her running and lose weight at the same time.For all your breaking Glasgow news, click here, or head to our Facebook, Twitter and Instagram pagesWhen Gail began following the Food Optimising healthy eating plan, she discovered a love for cooking. She swapped her diet of chocolate, cakes and shop-bought-sandwiches for cooking healthy, wholesome meals from scratch including her favourite dish of chicken stir fry.She said: ldquoWhen my consultant explained the eating plan, I couldnrsquot quite believe that I could lose weight without going hungry, and still enjoy all my favourite meals just by making changes to the way I prepared and cooked them. Irsquove never eaten so well in my le! And I need all the fuel I can get for marathon training ndash so potatoes, pasta, and rice are all regularly on the menu! title: Iain Macwhirter  As May goes down for the third time  the road to Brexit just got a whole lot longer
story: The Prime Minister has behaved asshe had a thumping Commons majority when in fact she is a minority leader of an unstable coalition. Even after the Damascene conversion of arch-Brexiter Jacob Rees-Mogg, who used to described her deal as ldquovassalage, her final attempt to get a stripped-down Withdrawal Agreement through Parliament failed on Friday by a substantial majority. You have to give May full marks for her consistency: everything she touches turns to dust, even her own resignation.But thatrsquos by the by. As everyone has been saying: we are where we are. And where we are is extremely uncomfortable. Brexiters are gearing up to have a belly laugh at the opposition MPs, who will do their best throughout the coming week to find a compromise. Who do they think they are  Playing at being a provisional government  ldquoItrsquos like allowing the whelk stall to be run by the whelks, according to the Tory MP Sir Bill Cash. Butno-one  is able to run the eponymous stall, then all power to the whelks.Last weekrsquos indicative votes suggested that MPs are broadly in favour of a Brexit that keeps Britain in the EUrsquos economic loop while leaving the political institutions. Curiously, the SNP, who have been arguing for soft Brexit in two white papers and an election manesto, decided not to vote for the ious options, even the Norway model that they have long extolled. The SNP did, however, vote for the proposal from the Labour MP Margaret Beckett for a confirmatory ballot, and this option got the largest number of votes, much to everyonersquos surprise. This must be a serious possibility now that Parliament has failed to resolve the Brexit conundrum.However, this is not a Peoplersquos Vote as some have styled it. A confirmatory vote is not a rerun of the  referendum, but strictly a chance for voters to give their views on whatever deal Parliament agrees . The Kyle Wilson Amendment originally envisaged putting the Prime Ministerrsquos deal to a popular vote, assuming it was passed by Parliament. However, this confirmatory referendum might be dficult to schedule because it could collide with three other elections: a Tory leadership election, the European elections and a General Election. Brenda from Bristol will be in despair.EvenMPs fail to come up with a working compromise, they can still block a no-deal Brexit. The majority against leaving the EU without a deal is overwhelming. This means May, or her successor, will have to go cap-in-hand to Brussels in the next few days and request another, longer delay to Article . This would mean Britain participating in the European elections in May, which excites the Independent Group of Tory and Labour rebels, but is looked upon with dread by the main parties. Brussels too is worried about populist contagion spreading to other EU countries like Italy, but they are legally bound to make British participation a condition of any further extension to AVoter wrath, particularly in Labourrsquos leave constituencies, could lead to a dramatic revival of Nigel Faragersquos Ukip, or worse. The Svengali behind the  Vote Leave campaign, Dominic Cummings, is gearing up for the fight and reportedly suggesting a new party to fight for the right to leave. ldquoTell them again is the favoured slogan. The European elections might themselves turn into a kind of second referendum on Brexit.The Tories will presumably have a new leader by then, since Theresa May will surely go now there is to be the long extension she has resolutely opposed. Mind you, it is impossible to guess the Prime Ministerrsquos thought processes. She said she would goher withdrawal deal passed on Friday. But her gambit didnrsquot work. Even the opportunity to dispense with Mayrsquos services was not sufficient inducement for the Democratic Unionist Party to come on board. The joke doing the rounds last week was that she tried to fall on her sword and missed.But these things have a momentum of their own, and the Tory leadership election has already begun. Boris Johnson is the narrow frontrunner, but that could change. He might win the membership, but under Tory rules the parliamentary party has to agree the two candidates put to a postal ballot. The remainers in the Tory benches might use this as an opportunity to foil the hard Brexiters by keeping Boris off the list.Of course, what should happen when a government fails to get its most important legislation through Parliament is not a leadership election, but a General Election. The government cannot govern and, even with the Fixed-term Parliaments Act, this should lead to a General Election via a vote of no confidence. Some Conservatives might prefer to fight a General Election than European elections they had promised would never take place. But events are now out of everyonersquos control.Everyone, that is, except the EU, which now holds Britainrsquos future in the balance. Itrsquos trying not to crow about Britainrsquos abject national humiliation, but the , not the UK Parliament, will now decide the UKrsquos immediate future: deal or no deal. If MPs agree this week to back a soft Brexit involving the customs union and alignment with the single market, Brussels has promised to fast-track it in a matter of days. But the alternative, a long extension, will also suit the European Union.That means more money from Britainrsquos budget contribution, and serves as a warning to other EU countries about the dangers of trying to leave the Union. It also holds out the possibility of Britain remaining in the EU,a referendum is eventually staged.Well, that remains to be seen. What is perhaps more likely is that Britain gets stuck indefinitely in a long extension. It emerged last week that the Democratic Unionist Party, which again voted against Mayrsquos withdrawal deal, could live with a long extension. Indeed, they signalled that they could live with a customs union ndash as long as it ensured no border between Northern Ireland and the rest of the UK. The DUP may be Brexiters, but they are ardent Unionists first.A soft Brexit may now be the best way of keeping the UK together. But it should be put to the people in a confirmatory vote,for no other reason than this was not what most people thought they were voting for in . MPs have the opportunity to decide this tomorrow.How and why Theresa May failed to seek the only kind of Brexit that could get through Parliament will be left for historians to judge. One of her own Cabinet ministers, quoted on BBC Newsnight, gave the provisional verdict: ldquoShersquos the sole architect of this mess because of her inability to engage in the most basic human interaction. Who says personalities donrsquot matter in great historical events

title: dennis-kelly-on-writing-matilda-the-musical
story: ldquoFor a big musical, the show feels really theatrical, says Kelly, who wrote the show with composer and Edinburgh Festival Fringe favourite Tim Minchin. ldquoIt is polished, but it doesnrsquot always feel like it, which is great. To do the burp, we talked about loads of dferent ideas about how to do it and make it feel as though a burp had just happened, but in the end we went for something really simple, which works in big theatres, but which you could do in tiny spaces as well.The sort of spaces Kelly is talking about are exactly where the London-born writer began his play-writing career after joining a youth theatre while a teenager working in Sainsburyrsquos. His first play of note, Debris, was staged at the tiny Theatre , situated above a Battersea pub, in . He came to further prominence two years later when After The End was seen at the Traverse Theatre in Edinburgh in a production directed by Roxana Silbert for the Paines Plough Company.By , Kellyrsquos BBC Three sit-com, Pulling, co-written with Sharon Horgan, was en route to being nominated for a BAFTA, while his  stage play, Orphans, premiered at the Traverse in a Birmingham Rep production directed by Silbert. The same year saw the National Theatre of Scotland premiere Kellyrsquos play for children, Our Teacherrsquos A Troll. With such a relatively left-field back catalogue, being approached by the Royal Shakespeare Company, then led by former director of Glasgowrsquos Tron Theatre, Michael Boyd, wasnrsquot what Kelly expected to happen next.ldquoWhen the RSC came to me and said they wanted me to do a musical, I said I didnrsquot have a clue about how to do that, Kelly remembers. ldquoI think they knew my work from Debris and Our Teacherrsquos A Troll, and I wrote about three drafts and then Matthew Warchus came on board as director. They looked around exhaustively for a composer, and as soon as I spoke to Matthew about Tim Minchin, I think he knew he was the one.Minchin is the Australian-based performer, whose internationally renowned musical comedy show, Darkside, was an Edinburgh hit in , winning him what was then the Perrier Comedy Award for best newcomer. By the time Kelly and Minchinrsquos take on the story opened in Stratford in , both had been through an extensive development process.ldquoWe did four of these huge two-week workshops, Kelly remembers, ldquoand it was a lot of work. I donrsquot really like workshops, to be honest. I find that stuff hard. The first person I want to hear doing something Irsquove written is the actor playing the part, but with something this big you just have to get on with it and do it.Kelly reckons the entire process took about four years.ldquoSomeone said to me at the time that was ten per cent of my le, he says.Matilda The Musical looks set to last a lot longer than that. Following its West End transfer, the show opened on Broadway, and went on to win seven Olivier Awards ndash the most ever won by a musical ndash and five Tony Awards. It has also toured Canada and Australia prior to its current UK tour. Has such international success changed things for Kelly ldquoIn some ways it changed things, he says, ldquoand in some ways it didnrsquot. Irsquove had a show on for the last eight years, which feels strange. As a playwright you tend to have a show on, then it closes and another one goes on, so it is dferent with Matilda, but after all this time I donrsquot have a lot to do with it anymore. I donrsquot think Irsquom a lot of use to it. I used to go in and maybe give a bit of advice, but at some point yoursquove got to step back and let them get on with it.ldquoHow I wanted to work didnrsquot change. Itrsquos not like this was what I was working towards, meeting famous people and swanning round musical theatre or anything like that. I still write grimy little plays, and always have done, and writing Matilda was no dferent from writing anything  Irsquove done.Such a down to earth approach is part of Matildarsquos appeal. ldquoThere are two things I really like about it, Kelly says. ldquoThe first is Matildarsquos inability to accept the status quo, and secondly, she doesnrsquot whinge about it. A lot of the time in musicals, people say, oh,only this or that happened, I could have done this. Matilda never really does that. She just gets on with it and sorts things out. I think as well itrsquos a bit cheeky and a bit naughty as a musical. The great thing about Roald Dahl is hersquos rude, and Irsquom rude as well, and so is Tim, so it all came together because wersquore all rude. But apart from anything , itrsquos amazing seeing that little girl telling the story, and holding , people or a couple of thousand people, in the palm of their hand.Kellyrsquos forte charting the adventures of unruly small people has continued with his version of Pinocchio, which he wrote for the National Theatre in London in a production that ran in  and  directed by John Tfany, formerly of the Traverse and National Theatre of Scotland. In this way, Kelly seems naturally drawn to such fictional trouble-makers.ldquoBeing able to watch someone who is very small overpower someone who is very big, thatrsquos not a bad message, he says. ldquoI learnt very early on, kids hate things that arenrsquot fair. If you tell a kid off and yoursquore wrong, they hate it. I just love the idea that therersquos a little girl out there who gets up and sorts things out. We could probably do with a bit of that in the world just now.Matilda The Musical, The Playhouse, Edinburgh, tonight-April .www.atgtickets www.uk.matildathemusical

title: artists-invited-to-enter-new-grand-central-hotel-competition-for-gallery-of-portraits-of-the-famous
story: Now the starry history of Glasgowrsquos Central Hotel is to be captured in oil and pastel, pencil, print and paint, as the hotel, in tandem with The Herald, launch unique competition for artists to adorn a new central gallery space.The hotel, since its first opening in , as been the host to a historic guestlist of stars, politicians, and celebrities.The Grand Central is opening a competition, asking artists of all kinds and levels of experience, to create a portrait of one of its famous residents - the winning dozen or so images will then have the opportunity to be displayed as part of a new gallery wallspace inside the hotel.The hotel, a key landmark in Glasgow right next to Central Station, has played host to some remarkable names over the years: Gene Kelly and Laurel and Hardy, Sir Winston Churchill and President John F Kennedy.Frank Sinatra was there, as was Nat King Cole, Danny Kaye, Sammy Davis Jnr, and The Beatles.Cary Grant brought his Hollywood elegance to the hotel, as did Vivien Leigh and Jean Simmons.Roy Rogers and Trigger spent time there - with both silver screen cowboy and his horse lsquosigning inrsquo at the front desk - as well as Bob Hope, Mick Jagger and Billy Connolly.Crowds would gather outside the hotel when stars came to stay in the s, with thousands screaming for Abbott and Costello when they stayed.President Kennedy was at the hotel as a young man: he was at the hotel in , with his father, Joseph Kennedy, US Ambassador to the UK, and Churchill stayed at the hotel in  and .Artists are being invited to paint, sketch, draw, and otherwise create images of one of these figures, chosen from the list below, for the Grand Central Hotel Portrait competition.Once artists have completed their portrait or portraits - on canvas or paper, or wood or other material - they can email an image of them to the address below, with a deadline of June .A judging , including the art critic and writer Jan Patience, and Paul Bray, general manager of the Grand Central, will whittle the entries down to a short list in July.The short-listed art works will then be judged at the hotel in the summer.Yesterday, Glasgow-based Colombian artist Diana Quintana, who has begun work on a portrait of Davis Jnr, helped kick off the competition.By September, the final winning portraits will be chosen and unveiled: the finished works will then be displayed long-term on a wall in the central stairwell of the hotel.Mr Bray, whose hotel will become part of the Voco brand of hotels in , said he is open to all kinds of art style or material - as long as it is long lasting and can be hung on the wall - for the competition, which is open to all artists: amateur, enthusiast, student or professional.Tens of thousands of guests at, and visitors to, the hotel will pass by and have a chance to view the gallery display.He said: ldquoEverybody who visits the hotel stops to look at the photographs in the corridor: therersquos Gene Kelly, and the images of people queuing outside the hotel during the Glasgow Fair about to go on their holidays, and this struck us as an opportunity to dig into its history.ldquoLetrsquos look at the superstars of the silver screen, from its early days in the s and s-and more recently in the s and s and who also frequented the hotel- and letrsquos showcase them.ldquoIt is a great opportunity for artists.ldquoIt doesnrsquot have to be an immaculate piece, they can be in any style that they want to do: it could be charcoal, it could be oil, it could be pastel, it could be watercolour, whatever somebody wants to do, as long as it fits the criteria of the quality we are looking for, we will display it up there for the world to see.Mr Bray added: ldquoYou are talking about hundreds of thousands of people passing through our doors, we sell over , bedrooms a year, and then you have people coming to the Champagne Bar, and there are upwards of , people a week passing through those doors.ldquoIt is fantastic prominent place for people to show their artwork and for us to create an artistic feature for people to enjoy when they visit.Donald Martin, editor-in-chief of Newsquest Scotland and Editor of The Herald, said: ldquoWe are delighted to be part of this exciting competition in partnership with the Grand Central Hotel.ldquoThe Herald greatly values the arts and our arts coverage, and we are eager to see how the nationrsquos artists will respond to this unique competition.Mr Bray added: ldquoI am the custodian of this hotel for this period of time, and I take that role very seriously.ldquoIn terms of that history, you cannot take that lightly: we are passing through this hotel, it will be here when we have left, but the time we are here we have got to make sure we do it justice.ldquoThis competition is about leaving a bit of a legacy for the future, so that people can help feel that connection.TERMS  CONDITIONS ndash GRAND CENTRAL HOTEL ART COMPETITION. The competition is open to artists worldwide, aged  and over, both amateur and professional.. Only original artwork completed within the period of the competitionwill be considered.. No entry should be larger than .cm x .cm . Entries do not need to be framed. All materialsare acceptable for your painting or drawing.. The artwork subject will be selected from a list of ldquofamous faces who have stayed at the Grand Central Hotel during the course of its history. No other subjects outside the list will be allowed. The list is as below:Winston ChurchillMae WestJohn F KennedyPrincess MargaretNat King ColeCharlie ChaplinAbbott  CostelloFrank SinatraBing CrosbyFred AstaireDanny KayeSammy Davis JuniorJean SimmonsRoy Rogers  TriggerBilly ConnollyThe BeatlesCary GrantVivien LeighMick JaggerBob HopeGene Kelly. To enter, enter digital files of your images to marketing@theherald. Closing date for entries is pm Sunday, June th ... When submitting your competition entry, you must provide your name, address, email and contact telephone number. We will only use this information in relation to the competition and will not use it for any other purposes whatsoever. We will not keep this information for longer than is necessary for the operation of the Competition..Entries will be judged after June  and selected works called for a judging exhibition in mid-July. All artworks entered must be available for judging exhibitionselected... All care will be taken with entries but no responsibility can be accepted for loss or damage in transit, incoming or outgoing, whilst on the Grand Central Hotel premises or during the judging exhibition. Original artwork selected and submitted for the final judging exhibition will be insured by the artist.. Original artworks must be left with the organisers throughout the judging exhibition.. All entries must be original artworks by the submitting artist. Submission of entry in this competition automatically constitutes acceptance of all the competition rules and agreement to allow the competition organisersto publish and repurpose entries in print and digital formats including but not limited to, newspapers, magazines, promotional materials, websites, postcards, databases and as part of downloadable digital products.. Submissions must be the artistsrsquo own work, please do not enter ed art.infringement will be breached by the artist who submits the work and not by the competition organisers.. The judgesrsquo decisions will be final and binding. We will not correspond or communicate on winning entries.. Twelve to  winners will be selected from the published list of subjects . The winnersrsquo artwork will be displayed permanently in the Grand Central Hotel.. Artist entrants retain theof their original artworks but grant to the Grand Central Hotel a perpetual non- exclusive royalty-free licence to display their artwork across all media, including online s, and to display the artworks in the hotel. For the avoidance of doubt, no fees or expenses will be paid for the creation of any part of the entry.. By submitting a piece of artwork the entrant is deemed to have understood and accepted these terms and conditions.. Judging Criteria:Fitting with the overall theme of the competitionCreative impactOriginality. title: rusting-in-dock-the-nuclear-subs-that-wont-be-scrapped-until-2060s
story: Now spending watchdogs have condemned defence chiefs for their ldquodismal failure to scrap its rusting fleet of obsolete nuclear submarines.Ministry of Defence chiefs have admitted it will take until the late s to defuel and dismantle  disused boats currently in storage, seven in the Rosyth yard on the Forth.But the UKrsquos main financial watchdog has warned there are are still no plans for how to dispose of submarines currently at sea, including the four Vanguard-class Trident missile carriers.:Hundreds of peace campaigners stage rally at nuclear submarine base HMNB ClydeIn a scathing report, the National Accounts Officedetailed a history of soaring costs, prolonged delays and technical indecision about what to do with the obsolete subs.The MoD has now estimated over the next  years it will need pound. billion to maintain, dismantle and defuel its decommissioned nuclear submarines and  more currently at sea. The bill for each boat is estimated at under poundm.Labour MP Meg Hillier, the chairwoman of the Commons Public Accounts Committee, said: ldquoFor more than  years the Ministry of Defence has been promising to dismantle its out-of-service nuclear submarines and told my committee last year that it would now address this dismal lack of progress. It has still not disposed of any of the  submarines decommissioned since  and does not yet know fully how to do it.ldquoThe disposal programmes have been beset by y delays and spiralling costs, with taxpayers footing the bill. The ministry needs to get a grip before we run out of space to store and maintain submarines and we damage our reputation as a responsible nuclear power.Nine of the vessels ndash all at Devonport near Plymouth ndash still contain irradiated fuel. No boat has been defuelled since  after a regulator ruled the UK lacked the facilities to do so. The MoD is currently trying to recreate a capacity to remove fuel from the submarines. In  the price for this was estimated at poundm. It is now expected to cost poundm.:Hundreds of Police Scotland vehicles are more than a decade oldA deadline for getting such technology up and running has gone from  to , while the average number of years submarines have been stored with fuel is nine years.All stored submarines are at facilities run by the engineering company, Babcock. It has seven boats at its Basin Three at Rosyth in Fe which all have had their nuclear fuel removed. The oldest, HMS Dreadnought, has been at the site since . The others were decommissioned in the s and are Churchill and Swtsure and the old Polaris nuclear missile boats, Revenge, Resolution, Renown and Repulse. NAO in its report said it was unclear whether there would be space for the bigger Trident submarines at Rosyth.Environmentalists have been warning that authorities just have not figured out how to deal with their old nuclear-powered boats. Five years ago Greenpeace said ldquothe UK has failed to identy a long-term storage disposal option for nuclear waste and that this problem will not be solved within the coming decades.Delays have not just hit defuelling as dismantling is also way behind deadline. NAO said the MoDrsquos deadline for ruling out a tested dismantling scheme had stretched from  to .The report continued: ldquoIn  the department also outlined its requirement to lsquodismantle  defuelled submarines by  in a safe, secure and sustainable manner which upholds reputation as a responsible nuclear operatorrsquo. Following delays, it now estimates to fully dispose of these submarines by the late s, up to  years later than envisaged, and roll out its approach by , representing a -year delay.America, France and Russia dispose of submarines by removing an entire reactor block. The US has scrapped more than .The NAO warned new ways of breaking up newer boats would also have to be developed. It said: ldquoThe department does not have a fully developed plan to dispose of Vanguard, Astute and Dreadnought-class submarines, which have dferent types of nuclear reactor. Within the civil nuclear sector, organisations must consider waste disposal during the design stage. The department does not have a similar obligation.A MoD spokesman said: ldquoThe disposal of nuclear submarines is a complex and challenging undertaking. We remain committed to the safe, secure and cost-effective de-fuelling and dismantling as soon as practically possible.

title: tory-brexiteers-condemn-theresa-mays-handing-over-brexit-process-to-corbyn-a-known-marxist
story: They warned the lurch to a softer Brexit would cost the Conservative Party votes in future elections as the Prime Ministerrsquos proposal could potentially result in the Tory Government breaking its manesto pledge not to see Britain remain in the European Unionrsquos single market and customs union.Boris Johnson expressed disappointment the Cabinet had entrusted the ldquofinal handling of Brexit to the Labour leader and his party."The PM and Cabinet have concluded any deal is better than no-deal...one that leaves us being run by the EU. I can under no circumstances vote for a deal involving a customs union as that does not deliver on the referendum," said the former Foreign Secretary.His fellow Brexiteer Jacob Rees-Mogg noted: ldquoGetting the support of a known Marxist is not likely to instil confidence in Conservatives."The Somerset MP said Mrs Mayrsquos announcement was an attempt to overturn the referendum that wanted a clear Brexit ldquoto do a deal with a Socialist who doesnt want Brexit and is not in line with the Conservative Partys manesto commitments or with the referendum.Her offer to Mr Corbyn was welcomed by the Labour leader, who said he was ldquovery happy to meet the PM, insisting he would ldquonot set any limits on the talks.It came in a statement in Downing Street after a marathon seven-hour Cabinet meeting, described as ldquoisive and ldquotense.The PM - who is expected to meet the Labour leader on Wednesday - made clear that to avoid Britain crashing out of the EU on April , she would seek from Brussels a further extension to the Article  process it would be ldquoas short as possible and end once a deal were passed.But the proposal split the Cabinet  to  with the majority against. However, a ldquokey intervention by Geoffrey Cox, the Attorney General, proved decisive and the Cabinet ldquocollectively agreed the move.At one point, Chancellor Philip Hammond called for a general election or a second referendum to resolve the Brexit issue but this was received badly by colleagues. It is also believed the issue of a national unity government was discussed but not agreed to.After the am to pm Cabinet, fuelled by Chilean red wine and sandwiches, Mrs May addressed the TV cameras from inside No , saying: ldquoThis debate, this ision, cannot drag on much longer. It is putting MPs and everyone  under immense pressure and it is doing damage to our politics.She announced she was taking action to ldquobreak the logjam by offering to sit down with the Labour leader to ldquotry to agree a plan that we would both stick to, to ensure we would leave the EU...with a deal.But she stressed it would have to abide by the current negotiated Withdrawal Agreement meaning the party leaders had to focus solely on the future relationship with the EU.The ldquoideal outcome would be an agreed approach on a future relationship that delivered on the referendum result, which could put to MPs for approval and which she could then take to next Wednesdayrsquos European Council.But Mrs May explainedshe and Mr Corbyn could not agree on a ldquosingle unied approach, then a run-off would take place possibly on Monday. This would involve a number of options put before MPs in a series of votes to determine the way forward.ldquoCrucially, explained the PM, ldquothe Government stands ready to abide by the decision of the House. But to make this process work, the Opposition would need to agree to this too.This means that, , say, the Commons backed a customs union option, Mrs May would be duty-bound to take it to the EU.Once an option were agreed to, the Government would then bring forward the Withdrawal Agreement Bill, which it would want to agree a timetable for to ensure it was passed before May , so Britain need not take part in Euro elections.ldquoThis is a dficult time for everyone, declared the PM. ldquoPassions are running high on all sides of the argument. But we can and must find the compromises that will deliver what the British people voted for. This is a decisive moment in the story of these islands and it requires national unity to deliver the national interest.Mr Corbyn stressed his partyrsquos plans for a customs union and access to vital markets as well as consumer, environmental and employment protections would be on the table. So too would an ldquoabsolute guarantee the Good Friday Agreement was maintained for peace in Northern Ireland.The Labour leader said, while the PM had thus far not compromised, he was pleased she had reached out.ldquoHowever people voted in the referendum of , they didnrsquot vote for lower living standards or to lose their jobs. And therersquos far more that unites people on both sides than ides them, he added.Ian Blackford for the SNP denounced Mrs Mayrsquos ldquocan-kicking statement, saying it merely prolonged the Brexit agony instead of providing clarity on a way forward.He added: ldquoWhat the Brexit fiasco is proving beyond doubt is that Scotland is not an equal partner in the UK and the only way to properly protect our national interests is with independence.

title: iain-macwhirter-time-to-keep-calm-and-prepare-for-a-no-deal-brexit
story: A catharsis would at least end this agony of indecision. It would impose reality on the whole debate, as it became clear to Leavers what it means to lack negotiated trading relations with our largest trading partner.:Iain Macwhirter: Time to keep calm, and prepare for a No Deal BrexitThere would be a General Election, and the Tories would likely be destroyed for a generation. The case for Scottish independence would be greatly enhanced, evena second referendum is currently off the agenda. And anyway, Britain would have toto the negotiating table within months, even to negotiate a free trade arrangement.No deal is not something I would advocate, obviously. But events are beginning to take on a le of their own. Perhaps Parliament will come to its senses, but the arithmetic is against it. Soft Brexit needs to win a convincing and sustainable majority of the  MPs, and so far it hasnrsquot come close. Conservative MPs are refusing to compromise, as an emotional Nick Boles remarked as he left his party. But they are also refusing to vote for Theresa Mayrsquos Withdrawal Agreement, which leaves us with nowhere to go.:Brexit crisis: Tories at breaking point as Theresa May makes offer to Jeremy CorbynThe SNP, to its credit, laid aside party advantage and tried to get Mr Bolesrsquos Common Market . motion passed. Labour MPs also voted in large numbers for options which were not party policy. But at best, only  Conservatives seem minded to seek a consensus, and frankly that ainrsquot enough. Mrs May will probably put her broken deal back to Parliament in Meaningful Vote  ndash but unless Labour abstains it will be defeated again. If we are heading for a crash, we need to prepare.Would there be civil unrest  The Government has certainly prepared for it, and the Army is on standby to deal with trouble at the ports. The Cabinet Secretary, Sir Mark Sedwill, estimates that food prices would rise  per cent, which seems likely, but I doubtpeople would take to the streets on the back of that. The Brits are a phlegmatic race and they would probably just queue, singing Clf Richardrsquos greatest hits to keep themselves amused. Medical supplies will probably get through, eventually, though some will suffer. EU citizens are not going to revolt ndash most of them have already made plans to leave.Irsquom not trying to paint a rosy picture of No Deal. It is not an option that any rational government should contemplate. But Britain has ceased to be rational, and Parliament has failed in its key role as a means of building national consensus. Remainers shouldnrsquot exaggerate the immediate problems of No Deal Brexit, as they did before the  referendum. It is partly the failure of the forecasts of Project Fear to materialise that has made many voters relaxed about leaving without a deal. At least until their jobs start to go.There wonrsquot be mass redundancies overnight, but rather a slow attrition of businesses and jobs as Britain loses friction-free access to its biggest market. Brussels has made clear that it will impose tarfs,  per cent on cars, up to  per cent on some food products. But many items are already exempt and itrsquos not asthere is going to be a blockade at the ports.There will be the full range of sanitary and phytosanitary checks on food and agricultural products. There will be the gamut of regulatory checks also, but these are not immediately visible. Those lorry parks in Kent will certainly be overflowing and the M will be disrupted for weeks, perhaps months. But eventually things will start to move again.Sir Mark Sedwill forecast, in his No Deal briefing, that another run on the pound would be likely. The prospect of car and pharmaceutical companies departing for Europe, along with the banks and legions of creative industry professionals, would make Britain a poor investment prospect ndash at least in the short term. Britainrsquos financial credibility would be in question, and borrowing costs would probably rise.Ireland will face particular dficulties under No Deal, which is why Emanuel Macron and Angela Merkel are holding emergency talks with the Irish Taoiseach, Leo Varadkar. Efforts will be made in the short term to keep the checks away from border posts, and they may be successful. But in the medium term, there is going to be a hard border. That is going to have profound economic consequences for Ireland, which sends nearly half its food exports to the UK.:Scotlands anti-Brexit charm offensive goes down a storm in EuropeThere will also be consequences for the peace process in Northern Ireland. Sir Mark forecasts Direct Rule ing to Northern Ireland, and that could destabilise the province. But in the immediate aftermath of No Deal, there will probably be a stunned silence, as political parties assess the economic damage.As for the rest of the UK, there will also be a breathless hush next Friday as everyone waits to see what happens. It will probably be an anti-climax. The consequences will be profound, but most will be delayed. And there is an upside for Scottish nationalists. This reckless disregard for the express wishes of Scotland, and her MPs, may have made the Breakup of Britain all but inevitable.

title: letters-the-unpalatable-future-face-of-toryism
story: Favourite to replace Theresa May is Boris Johnson. To say that he is willing to offend is an understatement. He managed to insult both Barack Obama and Donald Trump, which is quite spectacularly stupid given he sees the US as our main trading partner post-Brexit. However it is not only presidents he insults, though he did also insult the president of Turkey. He has also managed to insult the people of China, the citizens of Liverpool but perhaps most stunning of all black people when he referred to them as "piccaninnies" with "watermelon smiles". Is there anyone, no matter how committed a Brexiter and Unionist, who would want this inidual running the country The alternative would appear to be Jacob Rees-Mogg, but he is no less unpalatable. This is the man who retweeted comments by the German leader of the AfD, a far-right political party with Nazi sympathies. This is the Brexit hardliner who has moved his investment assets to Southern Ireland and who will benefit greatlywe can leave the EU before much stricter investigations into tax avoidance come into force. For those who believe that Mr Rees-Mogg is working for you let me remind you that this is the man who said that people who attended state schools were "as thick as potted plants" and added that they were not fit to stand for parliament.These politicians are motivated solely by self-interest and care little for the rest of the population. To quote Francois de La Rochefoucauld: "The name and pretence of virtue is as serviceable to self-interest as are real vices."David Stubley, Templeton Crescent, Prestwick.TORY Party isions which brought down Prime Ministers and precipitated David Camerons bid to appease his backbenchers by holding a referendum, the result of which ended his own political career, was only the prequel of what was to come. Laura Kuenssbergs BBC documentary The Brexit Storm was a useful reminder of the long saga of ministerial resignations, of the Conservative Partys bitter civil war, with the European Research Group operating as a party within a party and other Tory MPs quitting in disgust, and of Theresa Mays deal being rejected by Parliament, once, twice, thrice. And the common factor running through the current sorry mess, is of a Prime Minister who stubbornly believed that the only way was her way, and who refused to reach out and include not only her own colleagues, but other parties at Westminster and the devolved administrations in Scotland and Wales.As Ms Kuenssberg presented the story of how Mrs Mays Brexit intentions and negotiations unravelled, it became clear that given her intransigence, the current chaotic mess was always on the cardsthe foundations are rotten, everything is rotten, and as Mrs May built her Brexit house on sand, the tide was against it, and it, like the Conservative Party, lies ruined at her feet.Ruth Marr, Grampian Road, Stirling.YOUR front-page lead story todaycontains a quote from the hard Brexiter Mark Francois referring to the wishes of the . million who voted to leave the EU and how this was still on track following yesterdays votes in the Commons where once again MPs demonstrated their hopelessness,with the SNP at the forefront, by once again saying what they didnt want rather than what they did want.This .m number bandied about, usually with an attachment along the lines of "the democratic will of the people" is becoming tedious and repetitive. The electorate was  million so just under  million did not vote to leave and therefore . million is only the will of some of the people. Make voting compulsory, either by going to the polling station or postal voting. Yes, you can spoil your voteyou wish but apathy or laziness would not be allowed. Only then could any vote be given the "democratic will of the people" tag.James Martin, Thomson Drive, Bearsden.Read more: MPs publish emergency bill to stop UK crashing out of EU in  days timeWITH the current chaos surrounding the Brexit debate, the blame game is now in full swing with the opposition partiespositioning themselves to gain maximum advantage with the electorate rather than focusing on delivering the  referendum result.First, there is little mention that it was the EU who laid down the "red lines" in the Withdrawal Agreementand demanded that the legally-binding document must be passed by Westminster before any meaningful trade discussion could take place.Indeed the only reference to our future trading arrangements is a -page political declarationwhich sits beside the -page WA where it describes the future trading relationship between the UK and the EU. In other words, formal negotiations on everything it containscannot be discussed until the WA is ratied.Rather than vote for the WA which would guarantee an orderly withdrawal from the EU and give time to negotiate a trade deal, parties like the SNP and Labour have muddied the waters by insisting on voting about the political declaration which has inadvertently pushed Brexit towards the much harsher WTO rules. This is unacceptable, especially as the PM has already agreed that there will be much more cross-party involvement in any future trade negotiations.Consequently the PM has been right to focus like a laser to get the WA through Parliament as to date there is no other show in town currently acceptable to the EU to facilitate the prospect of a future trade deal. If the stalemate continues then a General Election must be the only way forward for the voters to vote down the MPs who have thwarted the referendum and increased the likelihood of a no-deal Brexit.Ian Lakin,Pinelands, Murtle Den Road, Milltimber, Aberdeen.AS I understand it, the argument for Brexit centres round ing sovereignty to the globally-respected Parliament in Westminster and negotiating better trade deals around the world than the EU can.Really  Thatrsquos working out well so far.Cameron Crawford,Woodlands, Serpentine Road, Rothesay.

title: theresa-may-set-to-hold-talks-with-jeremy-corbyn-today-amid-brexit-logjam
story: Mrs May said on Tuesday that she would seek an extension beyond next week to allow negotiations with the Labour leader aimed at ensuring the UK leaves the European Union "in a timely and orderly way".:Brexit crisis: Tories at breaking point as Theresa May makes offer to Jeremy CorbynMr Corbyn said he would be "very happy" to meet the Prime Minister in a bid to offer "certainty and security" to the British people - but Tory Brexiteers have reacted with anger.Jacob Rees-Mogg described the offer as "deeply unsatisfactory" and accused Mrs May of planning to collaborate with "a known Marxist".Former foreign secretary Boris Johnson said: "It is very disappointing that the Cabinet has decided to entrust the final handling of Brexit to Jeremy Corbyn and the Labour Party."And Conservative MP Henry Smith said Mrs May represents a "monumental failure of British leadership, a betrayal of the majority who voted to leave the EU and Conservative Party membership" - and said he could not "countenance her Corbyn Brexit process".The DUP said it "remains to be seensub-contracting out the future of Brexit to Jeremy Corbyn, someone whom the Conservatives have demonised for four years, will end happily".But Environment Secretary Michael Gove said he backed the talks with Labour because he wants to leave the EU.He told BBC Twos Newsnight: "One of my concerns has been that there are people within the House of Commons who want to frustrate that referendum mandate - there are people who want to do everything possible to prevent us leaving - and I wanted to ensure that minds are concentrated so that we do leave."The leaders meeting is expected to take place as a cross-party group of senior MPs launches a separate attempt to force the PM to stop a no-deal Brexit by tabling legislation requiring her to delay Britains withdrawal beyond April .A group of MPs - including Conservative grandee Sir Oliver Letwin and Labours Yvette Cooper - aim to fully pass a Bill through the Commons on Wednesday to stop the UK crashing out of the EU.:Letters: The unpalatable future face of ToryismIt follows the rejection of her Withdrawal Agreement three times in the Commons and failure of MPs to back any of the alternative proposals considered so far.Instead of initiating a third round of indicative votes on Wednesday, when Parliament once more has control over the Commons timetable, Sir Oliver will table a paving motion to allow debate and votes on Ms Coopers Bill. An amendment to his motion would set aside April  for indicative votes.The single-clause Cooper Bill requires the Prime Minister to table her own motion seeking MPs approval for an extension to the Article  process of Brexit talks to a date of her choosing.The group behind the Bill, which also includes former Tory chair Dame Caroline Spelman, Commons Brexit Committee chair Hilary Benn, former attorney general Dominic Grieve and Liberal Democrat Norman Lamb, hopes once it has passed the Commons it could be approved by the House of Lords and granted Royal Assent in time for the emergency EU summit on April .Meanwhile on Wednesday, the European Union will hold the first of a series of briefings on Brexit preparedness, while European Commission president Jean-Claude Juncker will speak about the UKs withdrawal in Brussels.European Parliament Brexit coordinator Guy Verhofstadt, who had said he thought a no-deal Brexit was "nearly inevitable", welcomed Mrs Mays offer of talks with Mr Corbyn."Good that PM @theresa_may is looking for a cross-party compromise. Better late than never," he tweeted.If the European Council proposes an extension beyond May , it is understood that it would be possible for the UK to take the steps necessary to prepare for European Parliament elections on May , but then cancel them at the last minutethe withdrawal deal was ratied.Following the mammoth Cabinet meeting on Tuesday, one source said ministers were split - against asking for a long extension to the Brexit process.But a second Cabinet source said ministers spoke - in favour of the limited extension sought by the Prime Minister, with just Gavin Williamson, Penny Mordaunt, Chris Grayling and Liz Truss opposed to the measure.

title: kelvinside-academy-unveils-plans-for-new-school-of-innovation
story: Kelvinside Academy will open Scotlands first School of Innovation, set in its west end campus, in October this year with plans to disrupt educationDesign of the new school will be based on an architecture studio model and will be built in partnership with construction firm Balfour Beatty as part of a pound.m contract.:Private schools to be hit with poundm bill amid plans to remove charity tax reliefLearning in the new school will tackle real-world challenges and collaborative problem solving rather than the traditional model of exams and results.David Miller, Director of Scotlandrsquos School of Innovation, said: ldquoThis is a must for Scotlandit is to continue to punch above its weight in the global economy during these challenging times. We truly believe we can and will transform education in the United Kingdom. We live in a rapidly changing world and schools need to provide an education which prepares young people to look at things dferently.ldquoGlasgow is the ideal place for the UKrsquos first innovation school. The city has a booming tech sector, is home to world class universities and some of the worldrsquos most creative and talented engineers, architects and designers.ldquoOur partnership with Balfour Beatty demonstrates the companyrsquos desire to address a nationwide skills gap. Although central to pupils attending Kelvinside Academy, we intend for the Innovation School to have an impact throughout Scotland and beyond.The building is beingdesigned and constructed using sustainable principles including circular models and eco-design.To mark a major milestone in its construction, Kelvinside Academy and Balfour Beatty hosted a lsquotopping-outrsquo ceremony this week to celebrate the achievement of the building reaching its maximum height.Kelvinside Academy school pupils are already benefiting from the partnership, with S and S pupil teams shadowing Balfour Beattyrsquos construction and design teams, learning from industry experts from the global construction giant, attending meetings, and providing feedback and input.:Nurseries urged to let children play in the great outdoorsHector MacAulay, Balfour Beattyrsquos Regional Managing Director for Scotland and Ireland, said: ldquoWe are delighted to be partnering with Kelvinside Academy, in a relationship which shares our vision of reducing onsite activity by % by the year  and will help us develop our future talent.

title: snp-accused-of-game-playing-on-peoples-vote
story: The Constitutional Relations Secretary told MSPs thathe could ldquowave a magic wand there would be a second EU vote, saying it was ldquoentirely right that it should happen.:Nicola Sturgeon set for Brexit crisis talks with Theresa MayHowever he then admitted the Scottish Governmentcould rejectthe outcome, saying it would be ldquounsupportablethe UK-wide result dfered from the one in Scotland.The Scottish Tories accused the SNP of ldquogame playing to pursue Indyref.Scotland voted - against Brexit in , while the overall UK result was - for Leave.The row broke out after Mr Russell gave evident to Holyroodrsquos finance and constitution committee about the current state of the Brexit process.With Theresa May due to hold talks with Jeremy Corbyn about breaking the impasse at Westminster, Mr Russell said: ldquoI would much rather not have a Brexit andthere is to be [one] I think a confirmatory vote is absolutely essential, given the changes that have taken place over the last two and a half years.He went on: ldquoI think that there should be a much longer delay. I think that people should be encouraged to have their say. A Peoplersquos Vote is entirely right to happen.ldquoIf I were able to wave a magic wand and get what I want, apart from no Brexit - which has been a complete distraction and disaster for the last two and a half years of massively damaging proportions - then I think it would have to be a very long delay, a referendum, the European elections taking place.However, around five minutes later, Tory MSP Murdo Fraser askedthe Scottish Government would accept the result of such a referendum.He said: ldquoIf there were to be a second referendum... giving a choice between the Withdrawal Agreement as it stands and Remain, and letrsquos say there was a narrow vote,  to  per cent, in support of the Withdrawal Agreement, would the Scottish Government then accept that needs to proceed :Iain Macwhirter: Time to keep calm, and prepare for a No Deal BrexitMr Russell replied: ldquoI think it would depend on what the vote in Scotland is... I think a situation in which the people of Scotland continue to support being members of the EU and were denied that option for a second time would be insupportable.ldquoThatrsquos the position we have. Wersquore not going to be able to change that today.Mr Russell acknowledged the Conservatives would disagree with him.He told Mr Fraser: ldquoYou and I disagree on this matter, wersquore not going to reconcile each other on this issue today. I suspect we will never reconcile each other.Mr Fraser said afterwards: ldquoMike Russell has made clear today that yet another referendum on Europe is, in his words, absolutely essential.ldquoAt the same time, Mr Russell also confirmed that the SNP will refuse to accept the result of that referendum unless it goes exactly the way they want it to.ldquoThis is all yet more SNP game playing. Far from compromising in order to deliver an orderly Brexit, the SNP just wants to use Brexit to create yet more grievance and constitutional ision. The only priority the SNP has is to deliver on its real goal - a second referendum on independence.LibDem MSP Tavish Scott added: "We need to find a solution to Brexit for the whole of the UK. The peoplersquos vote is the right way forward. The public are sick of political infighting and economic worry. With a peoplersquos vote we can make it stop.Pamela Nash, chief executive of the anti-independence group Scotland in Union, said the SNP had already ignored the results of the  and  referendums.She said: "The SNP has a track record of refusing to listen to voters. The Nationalists are trying to weaponise the Brexit crisis in the desperate hope of breaking up the UK.ldquoWhatever your views on Brexit, independence is not the answer. We are stronger together, and can build a successful future based on our shared history and culture."

title: university-of-edinburgh-to-honour-uks-first-female-medical-students
story: The so-called Edinburgh Seven were the first female medical students at any university in the UK.They were not allowed to graduate after missing out on a narrow vote on the decision.:Pioneering lsquoEdinburgh Sevenrsquo th century female medics to be honouredA spokeswoman for the University of Edinburgh said they wanted to ldquoright that wrong on the th anniversary of their matriculation day.THIS IS VERY EXCITING pic lilaMxxvpmdash Dr Chloeuml KennedyApril , Sophia Jex-Blake, Isabel Thorne, Edith Pechey, Matilda Chaplin, Helen Evans, Mary Anderson Marshall and Emily Bovell will be awarded a posthumous MBChB on Saturday July .Professor Peter Mathieson, principal and vice-chancellor of the university, said: ldquoWe are pleased to commemorate the historic achievements of the Edinburgh Seven in this th anniversary year of them joining the University of Edinburgh.ldquoThese honorary degrees recognise not just their academic achievements but the signicant contribution these women made to widening access to a university education for generations to follow.The Royal College of Surgeons of Edinburgh unveiled a plaque commemorating the medicsrsquo achievements last March.The institute is also launching an appeal for family members of the seven women to come forward ahead of the ceremony.Few photos exist of the women in the universityrsquos archives and it is hoped family or others could also help with this.Any family members of the Edinburgh Seven, or those with photographs, are asked to contact press.office@ed.ac.uk.

title: in-full-president-juncker-says-eu-should-be-prepared-to-accept-delay-to-article-50
story: It comes after Theresa May announced on Tuesdaythat she would seek an extension beyond next week to allow further negotiations.Read more:Theresa May set to hold talks with Jeremy Corbyn today amid Brexit logjamSpeaking at aplenary session today, Jean-Claude Juncker said thatMPs pass the Withdrawal Agreement before April , the EU should be prepared to grant an extension.Here is his statement in full:"The developments in Westminster over the past days have convinced me of what I already knew. The best way forward is the ratication of the Withdrawal Agreement. It has already been agreed by the Government of the United Kingdom, endorsed by this House as well as by the European Council."In its decision ten days ago, the European Council paved the way for an extension of the Article  negotiation period until the  May ndash on the condition the Withdrawal Agreement was approved by the House of Commons by  March. This was not the case.Read more:MPs reject Theresa Mays Withdrawal Agreement"In light of Prime Minister Mays statement last night, I believe we now have a few more days. If the United Kingdom is in a position to approve the Withdrawal Agreement with a sustainable majority by  April, the European Union should be prepared to accept a delay until  May."But  April is the ultimate deadline for the approval of the Withdrawal Agreement by the House of Commons. If it has not done so by then, no further short extension will be possible. After  April, we risk jeopardising the European Parliament elections, and so threaten the ing of the European Union."The Withdrawal Agreement is and has always been a compromise. A fair compromise in which both sides obtained some but not all of what they sought. It is the kind of compromise through which the European Union was built. The kind of compromise that enables the European project to advance. The kind of compromise we need at the moment."Much of the debate in the House of Commons has related to the future relationship between the European Union and the United Kingdom. The European Union stands ready to add flexibility to the Political Declaration, to pave the way for a close economic partnership between the European Union and the United Kingdom in the future.Read more:Could the Brexit chaos result in another general election "We stand ready to refer to a range of options, from a free trade agreement, to customs arrangements, to a Customs Union all the way to the European Economic Area. The openness we have shown from the start could be laid out, in purest clarity."On the EU side, we stand ready to launch the talks and negotiations on the future partnership as soon as the Withdrawal Agreement is signed. Before the ink is dry. The Commissions negotiating team is in place. Michel Barnier, our Chief Negotiator, is ready. I would expect the same level of readiness on the United Kingdom side."Whether this happens or not depends on the United Kingdom. The European Council gave the United Kingdom the time and the space to decide."Yet I believe that a ldquono deal at midnight on the  April is now a very likely scenario. It is not the outcome I want. But it is an outcome for which I have made sure the European Union is ready."We have been preparing since December . We have always known that the logic of Article  makes a ldquono-deal the default outcome. We have long been aware of the balance of power in the House of Commons."In that time, the Commission has published  preparedness notices,  non-legislative acts,  legislative proposals and  Communications. We have visited all  Member States to support their preparations. We have held  seminars with the Member States.Read more:At least EU, unlike strident Mrs May, has time for Remainers on Brexit, writes Ian McConnell"The measures we and the Member States have taken will mitigate the worst impact of a ldquono-deal scenario. The protection offered is real. The measures will make sure that EU and UK citizens can continue to live and work where they are at the moment. They make sure that planes can take off and land. We have adapted our financial instrument to make it possible to help fishing communities. We have identied the ways in which law enforcement cooperation can continue. We have taken steps to mitigate disruption on our financial markets."The measures we have taken are time-limited and unilateral. They provide a cushion for key EU interests at least until the end of the year. But disruption will be inevitable for citizens, for businesses and for almost every sector."The United Kingdom will be affected more than the European Union because there isno such thing as a ldquomanaged or negotiated no-dealand there is no such thing as aldquono-deal transition."And whatever happens, the United Kingdom will still be expected to address the three main separation issues."Citizens rights would still need to be upheld and protected."The United Kingdom would still have to honour its financial commitments made as a Member State.Read more:Herald on Sunday tells MPs to CHOOSE SOMETHING as Brexit teeters on brink"And thirdly, a solution would still need to be found on the island of Ireland that preserves peace and the internal market. The United Kingdom must fully respect the letter and spirit of the Good Friday Agreement."No-dealdoes not mean no commitments. And these three issues will not go away. They will be a strict condition to rebuild trust and to start talking on the way forward."At the European Council next week, we will listen to Prime Minister Mays intentions and decide how to proceed. The principles that will guide my actions are clear. I will work until the last moment to avoid a ldquono-deal outcome."The only ones who would benefit from such disruption are the opponents of the global rules-based order. The only ones who would cheer are the populists and the nationalists. The only ones who would celebrate are those who want both the European Union and the United Kingdom to be weak."The European Union will not kick any Member State out. I will personally do everything I can to prevent a disorderly Brexit and I expect political leaders across the EU and in the United Kingdom to do the same."

title: lack-of-teachers-limiting-school-subject-choices
story: Struggles recruiting specialist teachers is a key problem, especially for schools in rural areas, Gayle Gorman told Holyroodrsquos education committee.Ms Gorman, chief executive of Education Scotland, said some schools were finding ldquoinnovative solutions to teacher shortages, but conceded it was impacting on the choices on offer.Read more: Parents attack catastrophic cut to school subjectsLast summer, The Herald revealed schools across Scotland had more than  vacancies just weeks before the new school year.Our research showed shortages in key subject areas such as science, maths, computing, languages and home economics as well as in rural areas.The number of subjects being studied has also fallen as a result of the introduction of Curriculum for Excellence which places less of an emphasis on traditional qualications.The extra choice given to pupils to take a range of new courses has impacted on the uptake of languages in particular.Ms Gorman said: ldquoWe recognise there has been a reduction in some schools in curriculum offer. One of the major factors has been teacher numbers.Read more: Pupils studying fewer exams under new curriculumldquoThat is an issue that every school, and particularly those in rural areas, have found and do find challenging.ldquoA school should design a curriculum to meet their learnersrsquo needs. They need to be able to shape that with the best resources they have.Ms Gorman said some schools had collaborated to allow pupils to travel to dferent locations for certain subjects.She said such collaborations only applied to a minority of schools, but that Education Scotland wanted the practice to spread ldquoso that it becomes a majority.Ms Gorman was also questioned about research linking reduced subject choice with schools in more deprived areas.A freedom of information request by the Scottish Conservative Party last year found that in areas where a school has more than three-quarters of its pupils living in deprivation, the average offer at Higher is  subjects.In an area where less than one in four of the children at the school are living in an area of deprivation, the average offer is  subjects.Read more: School subject choice discriminates against disadvantaged pupilsHowever, Ms Gorman argued other factors rather than poverty were having an impact because of the additional money invested in disadvantaged schools through the Scottish Attainment Challenge.She said: ldquoOur evidence is showing the deprivation factor hasnrsquot been as signicant as expected.ldquoBecause of the additional resources schools have been able to continue to offer ... quite a wider range of curriculum.A committee survey showed nearly three-quarters of schools had dficulty recruiting teachers.

title: tory-msp-slated-over-new-health-service-gaffe
story: Michelle Ballantyne made the remark at the end of a Tory-led debate on health at Holyrood.Her critics suggested it was nod towards privatisation.The South of Scotland MSP was last year urged to resign after saying it was only ldquofair that people on benefit cannot have as many children as they like, a reference to the lsquorape clausersquo and related Tory benefit curbs that limit welfare to the first two children in a family.On Wednesday, the former nurse told MSPs the Scottish Government should not use the health service as a political football or micro-manage it.She said: ldquoIn fact, to be perfectly honest, as somebody who has spent a long time in the NHS, I would be quite happygovernment had nothing to do with the running of the NHS, quite frankly.As other MSPs reacted angrily, she went on: ldquoThat will never, ever happen because of the money around it. title: aldi on the lookout for new colleagues
story: Supermarket Aldi is now accepting applications for a number of posts in its stores across Aberdeenshire.The discount supermarket is looking for one Assistant Store Manager, six Deputy Store Managers,  Store Assistants and three Store Apprentices across its Aberdeen, Aberdeen City, Westhill, Cornhill, Ellon, and Inverurie stores.The majority of Aldi colleagues receive a minimum rate of £. per hour, regardless of their age. All colleagues will benefit from rising salaries during their service, with Store Assistant salaries across Aberdeen rising to £. from year two.For people looking to take their management experience to the next level, Aldi’s Assistant Store Managers are responsible for supporting the Store Manager to reach store targets and ensure the team is run efficiently. As well as a starting salary of £,, which rises to £, after four years, successful applicants will enjoy four weeks annual leave, rising to five weeks, and the opportunity to progress to Store Manager.Deputy Store Managers are expected to work closely with the Store Manager and Assistant Store Manager and will have the responsibility of managing store operations in their absence. Deputy Store Manager roles start from  hours per week, with a starting salary of £. per hour rising to £. per hour, plus £. extra per hour when managing the store.Hardworking and enthusiastic candidates are being targeted for Aldi’s Store Assistant positions, to carry out responsibilities such as accurate and efficient till operation, stock management and merchandising.Full training will be provided for Store Assistants over a six-week period and roles are available from  to  hours a week, with salaries starting at £. per hour, rising to £. per hour, and a realistic prospect of progression.During the Stores Apprenticeship Programme, Aldi Store Apprentices learn about every aspect of the store – from correctly unloading deliveries and managing stock rotation, to providing excellent customer service around the store and at the till.Store Apprentices will receive a salary of £ per week in year one, rising to £ per week in year three, and can now enter the Programme via two routes. The Career Starter is a new route introduced for March , which no longer requires candidates to have completed previous qualications. The aim of this new route is to allow apprentices to work towards a career, whilst developing skills in Literacy and Numeracy and completing a Level  Retailer Qualication.Alternatively, the Management Development Programme requires a minimum grade  or equivalent in Maths and English, and offers candidates a fast track path to becoming a Deputy Store Manager.Apprentices who choose this Programme will complete a Level  Retailer Qualication in the first year of training, and then progress onto achieving a Level  Retail Team Leader Qualication in years two and three.Richard Holloway, Regional Managing Director at Aldi, said: “As Aldi’s popularity and demand for award-winning products continues to grow, we’re in a great position to create a number of opportunities in the Aberdeen area.“As an award-winning employer, Aldi offers fantastic benefits, from competitive pay, a fantastic working environment and an abundance of progression opportunities for its colleagues. title: campaigner says kintore station must open as soon as possible
story: A local councillor who has played a leading role in the campaign for a Kintore station has said it must be completed as soon as possible and opened with the minimum delay.A delay in the expected opening date for the new station was announced in mid-March when Aberdeenshire Councils Infrastructure Services Committee received a briefing from Network Rail on the current railway works between Aberdeen and Inverurie.Commenting East Garioch cllr Martin Ford said: "I am surprised and disappointed that Transport Scotland is now indicating May  as their date for opening the new Kintore station. A planned opening date of December  has been in the public domain for many years without the rail industry expressing any alternative view."The dates of December  and May  are signicant because these are the points in the year when new rail timetables are introduced.Representatives of Network Rail attended a meeting of Kintore Community Council last week where the delay to the expected station opening date was not well received. Cllr Martin Ford was present at the meeting along with other Aberdeenshire councillors and community councillors.Cllr Ford added: "What I still want to see is Kintore station included in the December  rail timetable. If it isnt, the station cant open until the start of the next timetable in May  – evenall the building work is finished well before that."So put Kintore station in the December  timetable but with a note against it: Station under construction and expected to open during the currency of this timetable – see local announcements. That has been done where to allow new stations to be opened as soon as they are ready on completion of construction work."Its then up to Transport Scotland, Network Rail and the contractors to get the station finished as quickly as they can, so it can open as soon as possible, albeit after December  but before May ."It is believed that since Cllr Ford asked that Kintore station still be included in the December  timetable, Aberdeenshire Council transportation officers have made a similar request."We need Kintore station open and available for residents to use at the earliest possible date," said Cllr Ford.data-src"https:images-o.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"Gordon MP Colin Clark with Allyn Harper and Bryan Harper"  MP visits Insch firm viewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z"  Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "INVE | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "INVE | Article Teaser"

title: charity dog walk at haddo
story: The Great British Dog Walk is back for a fth year and is coming to Haddo House  Country Park on Saturday, April .Hundreds of walkers of all ages, and dogs of all shapes and sizes, will be ‘walking the walk’ to have fun, meet like-minded people and support Hearing Dogs for Deaf People.There are two route optionsmaking it ideal for dog owners, families, single walkers, organised walking groups and those who simply want to meet lots of dogs and get a bit of exercise for a good cause.Gill Yeates, National Fundraising Manager at Hearing Dogs, said: “Hearing dogs are real le-changers. Not only do they alert deaf people to important sounds, like the smoke alarm, intruder alarm and alarm clock, but they also provide constant emotional support, helping people to feel less isolated and enabling them to overcome barriers and reconnect with their communities.”There is a free limited-edition Great British Dog Walk dog bandana for each adult ticket purchased for the walk and working hearing dogs will be available to meet on the day.To sign-up or for more informationabout the event visit www.greatbritishdogwalk.org.Tickets are £ in advance or £ on the day.The Great British Dog Walk at Haddo starts at am. title: guests invited to join inverurie tea parties
story: A charity that provides a leline of friendship through afternoon tea parties is inviting older people in Inverurie to be their guest.Contact the Elderly would like potential new members to contact the organisation which arranges the free monthly gatherings for members of the older generation who live alone and who would enjoy some lively company.The charity, which has more than  groups across the country, recently welcomed its ,th guest in Scotland.Volunteer drivers collect guests from their home and accompany them to a gathering, usually in a local host’s home, where they can enjoy a couple of hours of tea, cake and conversation with like-minded friends.On other occasions there are opportunities to visit alternative venues – anything from a steam train to a museum – and members’ birthdays are often celebrated in style.One woman, who knew she wouldn’t receive a single birthday card or gt, was the happy recipient of  cards after she joined up.Caroline Peter, Contact the Elderly Support Officer, said: “The dference a little company and a change of scenery can make is amazing. We know just how much our regular guests look forward to catching up and hope to share that with some new friends.“Because our drivers provide a door-to-door chauffeur service it means guests, particularly those who find it dficult to get out and about, don’t have to worry about transport, which is a real bonus.“Our Inverurie group is really well established with a great team of volunteers and guests but we’d like to welcome more people to join the party. We’d love to hear from older people themselves or from anyone who knows someone they think would enjoy an afternoon out with us.”To find out more about becoming a volunteer or guest with Contact the Elderly in Inverurie, please contact Caroline Peter on   or email caroline.peter@contact-the-elderly.org.uk.data-src"https:images-o.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"Pupils make their way round the school during the challenge"  Walking challenge for Alehousewells School viewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z"  Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "INVE | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "INVE | Article Teaser"

title: have your say on local development plan
story: Aberdeenshire residents are being invited to submit their views to a consultation which will help shape the future of planning in the area.Anyone with an interest in local planning policy and land allocation for development is encouraged to take part before Monday, April .A Local Development Plansets out the policies that will be used for assessing planning applications and identies development opportunities in an area.The Aberdeenshire Local Development Plan  is currently being prepared and as part of that process, planners have produced a Main Issues Report .It is a document designed to create debate and comment, discussing all the bids received for development on sites across the area.Prepared by planners after initial discussions with communities and councillors, it outlines what needs to change in the current  LDP, and sets out preferred options alongside reasonable alternatives.This includes changes to the policies used to determine planning applications as well as additional land allocated for development.An invitation was issued early last year to the development industry and landowners to advise Aberdeenshire Council of which sites they think should be in the LDP, and why.It is not expected there will be signicant additional allocations of land in the next plan, although some sites in the existing plan that haven’t been developed could be replaced.The MIR also takes account of views expressed by Scottish Natural Heritage, Scottish Environment Protection Agency, Scottish Water, Scottish Enterprise, Nestrans, and Grampian Health Board.Eighteen issues are listed, relating to such matters as: Business Land and Town Centres, Tourist Facilities, Green Belt, Housing Numbers, Affordable Housing and Digital Infrastructure.The MIR consultation opened on January  and anyone can take part online, or view related documents at a local library until Monday, April .A series of drop in sessions have been taking place in communities so that anyone with an interest can discuss how the Main Issues Report may affect their area.data-src"https:images-o.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_
